parts.text: You are Syndi, a highly competent and helpful data assistant.

You are given this curation assignment as one of our top-performing data assistants:

A project has one or more table(s) within the project, where each table represents a dataset.
Your goal is to create high-quality dataset metadata for these tables that conform to the JSON schema below.
Also below is pre-summarized information from the project and tables that can be used for forming accurate and useful metadata.

The result will be submitted to an important data catalog; researchers depend on you! Here's your review checklist to help provide great results:
1. For fields like measurementTechnique, diseaseFocus, dataType, manifestation, use only the exact, predefined values specified in the schema's enum list. Do not use variations or other terms.
2. Ensure every field's value matches its required schema type; avoid using `null` unless explicitly permitted by the schema for that field.
3. The output MUST be valid JSON according to RFC 8259. Do not include comments.

# Project ID: syn24875850


# DNA methylation signatures in peripheral leukocytes of patients with Schwannomatosis or sporadic schwannoma

## Opening the Data Drawers Initiative
### Principal Investigator: Dr. Gelareh Zadeh
### Institution: University Health Network of Toronto

### Project Description: 
Aberrant DNA methylation is associated with cancer development and progression. There are several types of specimens from which DNA methylation patterns can be measured and evaluated as an indicator of disease status (from normal biological process to pathologic condition) and even of pharmacologic response to therapy. Blood-based specimens such as cell-free circulating nucleic acid and DNA extracted from leukocytes in peripheral blood may be a potential source of non-invasive cancer biomarkers. As part of our synodos for schwannomatosis study we focused on multiplatform genomic analysis of schwannomatosis related schwannomas. We also performed DNA methylation profiling on whole genomic DNA isolated from peripheral blood leukocytes from 27 schwannomatosis patients and 22 patients with sporadic non-syndromic schwannomas. This analysis was outside the scope of the synodos for schwannomatosis study; however, we were interested in evaluating the proportion of immune cell types in the blood of patients with peripheral nerve sheath tumors including schwannomatosis patients. After performing QC analysis, we removed 5 schwannomatosis samples (failed QC: detp>0.05). We then Removed 176834 failed probes (detp>0.05), 12613 probes on the X and Y sex chromosomes, 23507 probes associated with SNPs at the CpG sites, and 24267 cross-reactive probes. Total 630553 probes were left for clustering analysis. We then performed cell deconvolution analysis using IDOLOptimizedCpGs method  to determine the proportion of immune cell types in blood of patients with schwannomatosis or non-syndromic sporadic schwannomas including neutrophils, monocytes, CD4 T cells, CD8 T cells, B cells and NK cells. We then clustered the samples based on immune cell proportions. We found that schwannomatosis samples clustered separate from sporadic schwannomas. Our results suggested that schwannomatosis patients harboured a higher neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (NLR) compared to schwannomas. Further studies are required to determine the clinical implications of this result, in addition to continued work to uncover the biological underpinnings of these differences among these syndromic and non-syndromic disorders.

### Quality Assurance of the Data:

All data was processed using appropriate DNA methylation analysis pipelines including minfi from Bioconductor. We performed in-depth QC analysis as described above. Samples that did not meet our QC threshold were removed. All failed probes and probes associated with SNPs, X/Y chromosomes, and cross-reactive probes were also removed. Detailed QC results and associated graphs are ready available for uploading upon request.

# Project ID: syn21355225

# Evaluation of the use of antisense oligonucleotides as a personalized therapy for Neurofibromatosis Type 2 patients
## Children's Tumor Foundation DDI

### Principal Investigator: Dr. Elisabeth Castellanos
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: TBD
### Institution: Germans Trias I Pujol Research Institute (IGTP) & Hospital Universitari Germans Trias i Pujol (HUGTP)

### Project Description: 
Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a devastating genetic condition, characterized by the development of multiple tumors of the nervous system for which effective therapeutic options with no adverse consequences need to be developed. The clinical presentation of the disease is variable and related to the type of constitutional mutation in the _NF2_ gene inherited: patients affected with truncating mutations have a more severe form of the disease, while patients with missense, splicing or large deletions present a milder phenotype. 

In this context, the development of personalized therapies based on the type of _NF2_ mutation constitutes an opportunity. One of the therapeutic approaches that are being successfully developed for different hereditary diseases are therapies that act at the RNA level. Currently, it is possible to design antisense oligonucleotides (AONs) able to correct the effect of deleterious DNA mutations at the protein level, or to create proteins that still retain partial function from loss-of-function mutated alleles. AONs could be used to force the skipping of exons carrying truncating mutations when the reading frame is maintained. In this way, mutations that are associated to severe phenotypes could potentially be modified to less deleterious forms, associated to milder phenotypes. The NF2 gene is made up of 17 exons, 9 of them being in frame. Taken together, approximately 45% of the mutations detected in the NF2 gene could be susceptible to be treated by antisense therapy.

Here we propose to evaluate the use of AONs to reduce the severity of _NF2_ truncating and splicing mutations to milder hypomorphic forms _in vitro_. In addition, we hope to recover merlin function in cases where splicing mutation could be corrected. Based on our previous studies, we will induce skipping of in frame exons in primary fibroblasts derived from NF2 patients carrying truncating, splicing and missense mutations using specific AONs for each exon. The effect on merlin activity will be analyzed through different functional analysis. 

This work will allow the evaluation of the use of AONs as a personalized therapy for NF2 patients _in vitro_. The demonstration that the use of AONs reduce the severity of the _NF2_ truncating and splicing mutations, could open up the possibility to further studies using _in vivo_ models, thereby enabling to take a major step towards an effective therapy for NF2 patients.

${previewattachment?fileName=imatge%5F2RFA%2Epng}


Background: Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a genetic condition characterized by the development of multiple tumors of the nervous system. The clinical presentation of the disease is variable and related to the type of the inherited constitutional mutation variant in the NF2 gene. The use of antisense oligonucleotides (AONs), acting at RNA level, could be useful to correct the effect of deleterious DNA mutations at the protein level, or to create proteins that still retain partial function from loss-of-function mutated alleles. AONs They could be used to force the skipping of exons carrying truncating mutations when the reading frame is maintained. We have shown that a deep intronic mutation responsible for an aberrant NF2 splicing could be corrected by the use of PMOs and recover Merlin function. Here, we propose to evaluate the use of AONs PMOs to reduce the severity of NF2 truncating and splicing mutations to milder hypomorphic forms in vitro. 

Methods: Samples: primary fibroblasts cultures from NF2 patients. Phosphorodiamidate morpholino oligomers (PMOs)AONs: We designed specific phosphorodiamidate morpholino oligomers (PMOs) targeting four independent disease-causing splicing mutationsvariants, and a pair of PMOs to induce exon skipping of exons 4, 6&7, 8, and 11 of the NF2 gene. Primary fibroblasts carrying nonsense mutations variants were treated with the corresponding pair of PMOs. A dose-response and a time course study were performed to set-up conditions and confirmed the in-frame skipping of the target exons by RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing. Functional analysis: Functional studies were performed from fibroblast cultures untreated and treated at different PMOs concentrations. We measured: 1) Merlin, ERK and their phosphorylated forms by Western Blot; 2) actin cytoskeleton organization; 3) NF2 and YAP1 nuclear translocation capacity by immunofluorescence, and 4) proliferation capacity. 

Results: MutationVariant-specific PMOs for splicing mutations: our results showed the PMOs designed for splicing variants located at +/- 15 (or less) from the intron-exon boundary region, were not specific enough and interfered in the correct splicing signaling of both wild-type and mutated alleles. Exon-specific PMOs for truncating mutationsvariants: the effect of the exon skipping on both the mutated and the WT allele, although maintaining the NF2 gene reading frame at cDNA level, caused the complete loss of Merlin. Despite these results, complementary functional analysis are being performed to confirm the absence of Merlin at a cellular level.

Conclusions: PMOs might be optimal for inducing targeted exon skipping without altering gene transcription in cells carrying deep intronic variants, or for the modulation of alternative spliced exons. However, here we show that, in the case of NF2, PMOs may not be useful for correcting splicing when mutations are located in splicing canonical sites, neither for inducing semi-functional Merlin isoforms, since the use of these antisense molecules results in total Merlin los

# Project ID: syn4984604

${image?fileName=CTF Synodos Data Site Headers2%2Ejpg&align=Center&scale=100&responsive=true}
#The CTF Biobank
In 2013, CTF began a neurofibromatosis biobank to collect NF samples to better study the disease. With all samples being collected under the same protocol, the biobank enables comprehensive analysis of diverse NF samples.
---
##Cutaneous Neurofibromas
To showcase the value the biobank, **CTF** has kicked off a pilot project designed to characterize the molecular landscape of cutaneous neurofibromas (NF) that grow in NF1 patients, sponsored by the Children's Tumor Foundation. This project includes high-throughput data from 11 different patient tumors and matched blood samples.  These data are then compared with one another to assess the distinct landscape of cutaneous NF for each patient.  A manuscript describing this resource can be found [here](https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201745)
---

The project represents a collaborative effort between physicians, scientists and CTF to collect high-quality data from a diverse panel of cutaneous neurofibromas.
${image?fileName=newFig1%2Epng&align=Center&responsive=true}
---
##Data Release
The data can be downloaded directly from Synapse.  For details on how to get access to the data, navigate to the [data access wiki page](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn4984604/wiki/400545).

# Project ID: syn26347297

# The effects of RAS signaling pathway inhibitors on tumor cells and the tumor immune microenvironment in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors
## CTF Young Investigator Award

### Principal Investigator: Lindy Zhang
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Lindy Zhang, Christine Pratilas, Nicolas Llosa
### Institution: Johns Hopkins University

### Project Description: 
NF1-associated MPNSTs are resistant to MEK inhibition monotherapy because of activation of alternate cancer signaling pathways. This study will test combinations of MEK inhibitors, SHP2 inhibitors, and CDK inhibitors, which target different signaling pathways, to treat MPNSTs. Additionally, we will also investigate the role of the tumor microenvironment and the impact of various inhibitors on immune cells to design trials of immunotherapy drugs plus targeted drugs for MPNST.

# Project ID: syn11817821

The newly developed massively parallel technologies have enabled the simultaneous analysis of many pathways. There are several large scale international efforts to probe the genetics and drug sensitivity of cancer cell lines. However, there are some rare cancers that have not been analyzed in depth. One of these rare cancers is malignant peripheral nerve sheet tumors (MPNST). MPNST, although a rare cancer, are common in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1. We obtained funding from the Childrenâ€™s Tumor Foundation to fill this gap, in a novel way by enlisting students in a hybrid research/education model through what is likely to be the first course in high throughput screening. In the course, students will take part in a high throughput discovery effort in two phases. 

###Phase 1
Phase 1 is a training phase, which will consist of quantitative profiling the sensitivity of MPNST cell lines to a library of 130 common and experimental cancer drugs. These will be conducted in the UPenn High Throughput Screening Core with [Dr. David Schultz](http://www.med.upenn.edu/cores/High-ThroughputScreeningCore.shtml). While we call this a training phase, the data from this will be subject to rigorous quality control for eventual publication and development of a public database for rare tumors. Phase 1 will also include an introductory synthesis in the [Upenn/Merck High Throughput Experimentation Laboratory](https://www.chem.upenn.edu/facilities/penn-chemistry-high-throughput-experimentation-center).  

###Phase 2
Phase 2 is an independent research project. Examples of projects include, but are not limited to: Combinatorial screens (synthetic lethal); siRNA screens; novel compound screens; determining mechanisms of cell death; developing tools for data analysis and database development. During phase 2, students can also modify compounds of interest using the Penn Chemistry: Upenn/Merck High Throughput Experimentation Laboratory, and then retest them for activity to determine structure activity relationships. We will sponsor phase 2 projects relevant to neurofibromatosis. However, in phase 2 students can also perform experiments in other areas if they develop sponsorships from professors. We expect the course to be a hypothesis engine that generates ideas for further research.

# Project ID: syn4939876

##Combination Index Validation Studies (2 drug combinations)
**Initiative:** Cell Culture
 
**Name:** D. Wade Clapp, M.D. 
**Contact Email:** dclapp@iupui.edu
**Dates:** 7-15-15 to 12-31-15
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Validation Translational Model
 
**Background:** Preliminary High-throughput screening (HTS) data generated at National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS) implicated a number of different compounds as potential candidates and combinations suitable for moving forward to preclinical testing, with nine combinations prioritized for validation in murine primary embryonic Schwann cell lines and/or immortalized cell lines. 
 
**Goals of Project:** The goal of these experiments was to validate the results of preliminary HTS at NIH/NCATS by Dr. Ferrer.  
 
**Specific Aims:** 
1. Test the first two prioritized combinations in primary embryonic Schwann cell lines and murine plexiform-derived cell line (MTC): Rapamycin & Ganetespib and Selumetinib & Panobinostat.  
2. Compare the results of the Caspase-Glo and CellTiter-Glo reagents with those obtained by mouse tumor tissue (MTT) (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) in simultan
3. Compare the response of these two drug combinations in three different cell lines: 2 human derived NF1-/- cell lines (ipNF 95.6 and ipNF 05.5) and mouse pheochromocytoma (MPC)'s
 
${buttonlink?text=Back to the NTAP Data Portal&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Esynapse%2Eorg%2F%23%21Synapse%3Asyn4939478}

# Project ID: syn22267330

## **Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors Achilles Heel: Combinatorial Targeting of ERBB3 and Calcium Signaling**

### CTF Young Investigator:
#### Laurel Black

### Investigator Institution:
Medical University of South Carolina

### Abstract:
This proposal will investigate the role that ErbB3 and calcium-mediated signaling pathways play in regulating cellular proliferation and survival by in malignant peripheral sheath tumors (MPNSTs). At present, there are no effective treatments for MPNSTs other than radical surgical resection. After resection, recurrence typically occurs and so patients with MPNSTs have abysmal survival rates. The pathogenesis of MPNSTs is driven by Ras hyperactivation, a result of NF1 loss, and the loss of other tumor suppressor genes such as p53, PTEN and CDKN2A that negatively regulate cell proliferation/survival. Clinically targeting hyperactive Ras and its effector molecules has failed and so there is a desperate need to identify new therapeutic targets. We have focused on identifying Ras- independent and -dependent signaling pathways necessary for MPNST proliferation and survival using comprehensive genomic analyses, kinase phospho-arrays, pharmacological screens and several animal models. Our efforts have identified ErbB3 (a receptor tyrosine kinase/RTK) and calmodulin (CaM) as potential therapeutic targets in MPNSTs. Although there is conflicting evidence that other RTKs can drive Ras hyperactivation in MPNSTs, the role of ErbB3 has not yet been investigated in MPNSTs. Interestingly, our transcriptomic analyses of NRG1? (an ErbB3 ligand) stimulated Schwann cells and our global shRNA screens implicate ErbB3 and calmodulin-mediated calcium signaling as key biological pathways driving MPNST proliferation. With the cumulative support of our screens and functional analyses, we hypothesize that simultaneous inhibition of NRG1? activated effector molecules and calmodulin regulated signaling pathways will cooperatively inhibit MPNST cellular proliferation and survival. In Aim 1, I will test the hypothesis that NRG1? activation of ErbB3 directly modulates calmodulin regulated signaling in MPNSTs to promote cellular proliferation and survival. In Aim 2, I will test the hypothesis that dual inhibition of the NRG1? effector, ErbB3, and calmodulin effector molecules induces a cytotoxic effect in MPNSTs. This work will yield novel information about MPNST tumorigenesis by investigating the role(s) of ErbB3 (an upstream activator of Ras) and calcium signaling pathways (which can be dependent or independent of Ras). My ultimate goal is to identify a novel combinatorial treatment for MPNSTs using FDA approved drugs or drugs that are already in clinical trials that can rapidly advance to clinical trials.

### Acknowledgement:
Data was provided by:

**Black, L. E., Longo, J. F., Anderson, J. C., & Carroll, S. L. (2023). Inhibition of erb-B2 receptor tyrosine kinase 3 and associated regulatory pathways potently impairs Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor proliferation and survival. The American Journal of Pathology, 193(9), 1298-1318.**

The results published here are in whole or in part based on data obtained from the NF Data Portal (http://www.nf.synapse.org, RRID:SCR_021683) and made available through the NF Open Science Initiative.
**Accessing the data from this study requires a Synapse account.**

# Project ID: syn31619419

# Early treatment of cutaneous neurofibromas type 1 (cNF) to markedly improve patient's quality of life
## NTAP - DHART SPORE Developmental Research Program
### Principal Investigator: Thomas E. Milner
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Wangcun Jia
### Institution: University of California, Irvine
### Project Description:
The most common complication for neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1) patients is the appearance of cutaneous neurofibromas (cNF), which is considered as the most significant life burden of NF1. Current management of the tumors is eradication often with significant morbidity.

The goals of project are to improve the quality of life of NF1 patients through the identification of a biomarker to locate and evaluate cNF and through the development of a laser therapy solution. The proposed research has two aims. Aim 1 is to demonstrate an optical biomarker and validate using histology, and Aim 2 is to identify and demonstrate laser treatment mechanism of action. In Aim 1, two optical imaging modalities are utilized, Spatial Frequency Domain Imaging (SFDI) and optical coherence tomography (OCT) to first detect and then image tissue microstructure of cNF tumors. In Aim 2, two laser treatment modalities will be tested. The first treatment approach utilizes laser light to target the tumor vasculature to induce local hyperthermia and eradicate the tumor. The second treatment alternative utilizes near-infrared laser radiation to spatially target water and collagen to induce local hyperthermia and eradicate the tumor.

# Project ID: syn4939890

##Exploring the Plexiform Neurofibroma Interactome
**Initiative:** Open
 
**Name:** Jianqiang Wu
**Contact Email:** Jianqiang.wu@cchmc.org
**Name:** Kakajan Komurov
**Contact Email:** kakajan.komurov@cchmc.org
**Dates:** 5-15-13 to 11-14-15
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Biomarkers, Omics
 
**Background:** 

Adults with neurofibromas can be disfigured by thousands of neurofibromas and 25-50% of children with NF1 develop plexiform neurofibromas that can cause severe disfigurement and serious morbidity-- and death when they compress vital organs. Therefore, we focus on identification of therapeutic targets for plexiform neurofibromas.  

NF1 mutations in Schwann cells (SCs) drive neurofibroma formation; thus the primary neoplastic cell type in neurofibromas is derived from the SC lineage.  The SC genes that are deregulated in mouse and human neurofibromas have not been fully identified. Many cell types are present in neurofibromas besides SCs.  These include fibroblasts, mast cells, macrophages, and endothelial cells that are NF1 wild type (as in solitary neurofibroma or in somatic mosaic patients) or NF1 heterozygous (as in many NF1 patients and some mouse models).  But how these cells and the intercellular communications contribute to plexiform neurofibroma growth is unknown. It has been recently identified that macrophage is a major cell type in neurofibromas. Macrophages shift gene expression and function in response to the environment, including after nerve injury. Macrophages show anti- tumor effects by secreting free-radicals and recruiting the adaptive immune system (primarily T-cells). However as tumors progress, macrophages stimulate tumor growth and blood vessel formation. Injury-associated inflammation facilitates neurofibroma development by recruiting macrophages in mouse models. How these inter- and intra-cellular interactions contribute to neurofibroma formation has not been studied yet.
 
**Goals of Project:** 
1.  to characterize gene expression profiles of Schwann cells and macrophages in mouse nerves and neurofibromas
2.  to identify cytokine/chemokine pathways that slow or promote tumor growth
3. to identify molecular networks that mediate intra- and inter-cellular signaling in controlling neurofibroma growth.  
 
**Impact:** 
Schwann cell lineage cells are the cells of origin for neurofibroma formation. Macrophages are abundant in neurofibromas and play important roles in neurofibroma formation. Our findings suggest that SCs and macrophages interact each other within neurofibromas.  Specifically, Nf1-/- SCs promote a chronic inflammatory microenvironment to alter gene expression in both SCs and macrophages. Our analysis also reveals that neurofibroma SCs and macrophages both progressively adapt  to pro-inflammatory states during tumor progression, that is, neurofibroma SCs initiate tumorigenesis, while neurofibroma macrophages may maintain the pro-inflammatory state in the neurofibroma microenvironment and account for prolonged chronic inflammation.  The neurofibroma system described here provides a platform to investigate mechanistic aspects of RAS/Interferon signaling.  Our results suggest that targeting SC-macrophage interactions might provide a potential therapy for neurofibroma patients.
 
**Publications:** 
* Choi K, Komurov K, Fletcher JS, Jousma E, Cancelas JA, Wu J, Ratner N. An inflammatory gene signature distinguishes neurofibroma Schwann cells and macrophages from cells in the normal peripheral nervous system. **Scientific Reports** 2017 Mar; 7, 43315. DOI:10.1038/srep43315, https://www.readcube.com/articles/10.1038/srep43315

# Project ID: syn7217928

##Plexiform Neurofibroma Model Systems for Preclinical Drug Screening

**Initiative:** Cell Culture
 
**Name:** Ray Mattingly, Ph.D.
**Contact Email:** rmatting@med.wayne.edu
**Dates:** 5-1-13 to 4-30-16
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Preclinical Models
 
**Background & Rationale:**
Up to half of NF1 patients suffer with plexiform neurofibromas (PNs), for which there is no effective therapeutic approach. PNs are complex tumors that include a driving, deranged Schwann cell (NF1-/-) component plus other haploin sufficent (Nf1+/-) fibroblasts, perineural cells, mast cells and endothelial cells, together with secreted collagens and other matrix proteins. Surgery is the only current option for patients with PNs causing serious disfigurement or loss of function. At a recent NF patient forum in Detroit, it was reported that the high vascularity of these tumors can cause major problems during surgery. Most in vitro drug testing is still performed on cells growing in two dimensions (2D) on plastic dishes. In comparison to 2D cultures, cells growing in a 3-dimensional (3D) matrix that models the (patho) physiological environment typically: 1) adopt a morphology that better recapitulates that in vivo; 2) exhibit slower growth more akin to those in vivo; and 3) demonstrate drug sensitivity and resistance that may better reflect potential therapeutic response.
 
**Goals of Project:** 
Our goals were to develop and optimize robust 3D co-culture models of NF1 PNs to allow preclinical drug screening that is both much more representative of likely translational effectiveness than provided by testing in 2D mono-culture, and at a much higher throughput than is available in animal models. Further, we predict that programs such as the NF Clinical Trials Consortium are more likely to be successful if they build on data from robust and representative pre-clinical models. Our aims were therefore to: 1. Develop, characterize and optimize 3D co-culture models to include the cell types found in NF1 PNs; and 2. Test potential drugs in the 3D models of NF1 PNs, with a focus on candidates chosen for translational potential.
 
**Impact:** 
1. We have developed and optimized assays of cell proliferation that can be reproducibly used in 3D PN cultures and co-cultures and that will provide the basis for secondary screening of potential drug treatments. 
2. We have established and optimized what we believe to be the first 3D co-culture models of PN cells with endothelial cells. We suggest that these new models will provide an innovative way to investigate the clinically important aspect of the high vascularity of PNs. 
3. We have made major progress in the investigation of the interactions between the 3D PN co-cultures and their matrix through use of the live-cell collagen degradation assay. Development and refinement of this assay provides the groundwork for further studies on the pre-malignant phenotype of PNs.
 
**Publications:** 
1. Review article published: Brock EJ, Ji K, Reiners JJ Jr. & Mattingly RR. How to Target Activated Ras Proteins: Direct Inhibition vs. Induced Mislocalization. **Mini Rev Med Chem.** 2016 ; 16(5): 358â€“369. PMID: 26423696, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4955559/pdf/nihms802301.pdf

Roles of pericellular proteases in tumor angiogenesis: therapeutic implications, ch14, in Extracellular Targeting of Cell Signaling in Cancer: Strategies Directed at MET and RON Receptor Tyrosine Kinase Pathways.  Janetka J (Ed). Wiley, 2018, ISBN: 9781119300212

# Project ID: syn61696875

# Supplementing The Children's Tumor Foundation-Neurofibromatosis Registry with Electronic Health Record Dataset from Mayo Clinic Rochester
## CTF - Contract Award
### Principal Investigator: Mayowa Osundiji
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Mayowa Osundiji, Marlene Girardo
### Institution: Mayo Clinic Arizona
### Project Description:
The development of disease registries is a topical issue. Registries are robust resources that hold great promise for improving our understanding of disease processes, therapeutic responses and for enhancing the recruitment of patient populations into clinical trials. The Childrenâ€™s Tumor Foundation (CTF) Neurofibromatosis (NF) [CTF-NF] registry provides a unique opportunity to study and improve NF clinical care. The CTF-NF registry utilizes web-based approaches for gathering patient reported clinical history. Although robust, the CTF-NF registry in its current form may potentially be limited by patient recollections and understanding of pertinent details of their clinical history. In the studies proposed herewith, we will complement the CTF-NF registry by extracting de-identified NF clinical data directly from electronic health records (EHRs) at Mayo Clinic to improve the CTF-NF registry. Individuals with NF have an increased risk of developing some types of cancers, and many other health concerns. Considering the health risks that can accompany NF, regular clinical surveillance is critical in the overall care of NF patients. A wealth of dataset is continuously generated during NF clinical surveillance. We will extract de-identified forms of the most relevant NF dataset at Mayo Clinic Rochester (estimated patients number is > 1000) into CTF-NF registry. The proposed preliminary studies will help pave the way for multi-institutional EHR driven enhancement of the current CTF-NF registry. The studies will help develop a protocol that may also be used for batch collection and importation of NF data from EHRs in other institutions onto the CTF-NF registry. Expanding the current CTF-NF registry to a multi-institutional EHR driven NF registry holds great potential for improving our current understanding of NF disease processes and for refining clinical management strategies. The proposed studies hold great promise for improving the accuracy of CTF-NF registry and providing novel insights into NF clinical management in line with the CTF's mission to drive research, expand knowledge and advance care.

# Project ID: syn2343195

${image?fileName=CTF Synodos Data Site Headers4%2Ejpg&align=Center&scale=100&responsive=true}
#### ->*Creating tools and treatment paradigms for NF2-associated meningioma and schwannoma*<-
---
### ->**Check out the the [2019 data release](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn2343195/wiki/400095)!**<-

${image?fileName=Screen Shot 2016%2D06%2D13 at 11%2E52%2E29 AM%2Epng&align=Center&responsive=true&scale=60}

Synodos for NF2 is a first-of-its-kind Neurofibromatosis research collaboration dedicated to defeating the rare genetic disorder neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2). This unique consortium brings together a multidisciplinary team of scientists from twelve world-class labs at academic and medical centers of excellence, who have pledged to work closely together â€“ sharing information, datasets, results and more â€“ at every step in research development, with the goal of speeding up the drug discovery process. The end goal of this effort is to find new approaches to the diagnosis and treatment of two primary NF2-related tumors:  schwannoma and meningioma. The expectation is to take the work from discovery to pre-clinical development, resulting in the development of an Investigational New Drug (IND) for NF2. _The consortium is funded by [Children's Tumor Foundation](http://www.ctf.org/)(CTF)_

----
->${buttonlink?highlight=true&text=NF2 Data Summary&url=https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn2343195/wiki/499423}<- 
->${buttonlink?highlight=true&text=NF2 Public Data&url=https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn6133098}<-
${buttonlink?text=Back to CTF Data Portal&url=https://nf%2Esynapse%2Eorg/Organizations/DetailsPage%3Fabbreviation%3DCTF&highlight=true&align=Center}

----

The Synodos NF2 project has generated several types of â€˜omic and drug screening data from NF2 tumor models of schwannoma and meningioma, including: 
* Low throughput drug screening data: A panel of rationally-selected small molecules and drugs such as mTOR and HDAC inhibitors were tested against human and mouse cell line models of meningioma and schwannoma. 
* Single-agent and combination high throughput drug screening data: A panel of 1912 drugs and drug-like molecules (the MIPE 4.0 library from NCATS) was screened in 6 cell line models of meningioma and schwannoma with NF2 wildtype or NF2 deficient status. In addition, 4 of these cell lines were screened with 6x6 and 10x10 point combination dose-response assays with this panel of drugs. Both raw and processed data are available. 
* Genomic variant data (structural rearrangement): Jumping library sequencing facilitates detection of chromosomal abnormalities such as pathogenic breakpoints. There are processed data (bam files) from 11 human and mouse cell line models of meningioma and schwannoma with NF2 wildtype or NF2 deficient status. 
* Gene expression: Raw (fastq files) and processed (bam, count, and differential expression files) RNAseq data were generated from an Nf2fl/fl mouse model dorsal root ganglion tissue and cell line models of meningioma and schwannoma. In addition, data were generated from cell line models of meningioma and schwannoma with vehicle control, or 12 different single agent or combinations of small molecule inhibitors. Data from the 2017 release and the 2019 release are both now available for exploration.
* Kinomics: Processed data are available from NF2 mouse model dorsal root ganglion tissue several cell line models of meningioma and schwannoma after treatment with a vehicle control or one of seven small molecules. Data from the 2017 release and the 2019 release are both now available for exploration.

# Project ID: syn11374349

###Modeling NF with human Schwann cells via tunable and reversible control of NF1 protein
 

#####**PI:**  Gabsang Lee, Ph.D.
**Johns Hopkins University**

 

######**Study Design:**  

We will combine the human Schwann cell specification system and temporal â€˜SMAShâ€™ control of NF1 protein to develop a humanized cNF model with hESCs (**Figure**). First, we will modify the NF1 locus by â€˜knocking-outâ€™ one allele of NF1 and â€˜knocking-inâ€™ the SMASh tag and Puro-selection cassette (as a donor vector) into the other allele. The Lee and Kim labs have been working on genetic editing in human pluripotent stem cells for over three years and have generated many â€˜knock-inâ€™ and â€˜knock-outâ€™ lines. After verification of the gene targeting and pluripotency of the selected clones, established NF1-/SMASh hESC clones will be subjected to our Schwann cell specification protocol. We will treat cells with the asunaprevir (ASv) chemical compound at different time points to assess any cellular and molecular changes, either in intact cells or isolated populations (SOX10::GFP+ neural crest cells, CD49d+ Schwann cell precursors and EGFR+ Schwann cells).

 

${image?fileName=lee%2Epng&align=Center&scale=100&responsive=true}

 

######**Deliverables:**
1. NF1-/SMASh SOX10::GFP hESC clones,
2. Frozen stocks of SOX10::GFP+ neural crest cells, CD49d+ Schwann cell precursors and EGFR+ Schwann cells upon NF1 loss (at least three vials for each cells, ~20,000 cells per vial), and
3. Cellular and molecular profiling of each cell type.

 

######**Expected Outcomes:**

The goal of this project is to generate a viable human Schwann cell model for cNF and identify differences in susceptibility to NF1 loss in different stages of Schwann cell development. In addition, we will provide the tunable and reversible method of control of NF1 expression (culminated in NF1-/SMASh hESCs) to the general neurofibroma and neurofibromatosis research community.

###**Welcome to the Synodos for NF1- Low Grade Glioma Site**

This site is the central place for all data related to the CTF-funded Synodos for NF1 - Low Grade Glioma project.  The wiki area and specific folders can be accessed by all members of the group from the menu on the left.

# Project ID: syn21984813

##Predictive Modeling Utilizing a Preclinical NF1-MPNST Platform Suitable for Precision Oncology
PIs: Angela Hirbe, David Largaespada

### Rationale
NF1 is one of the most prevalent cancer predisposition syndromes, affecting 1 in 2500 individuals worldwide. Approximately 10-13% of affected individuals will develop an aggressive sarcoma, the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST). One of the major barriers to the improving outcomes for these patients is the lack of preclinical models that accurately represent the genetic heterogeneity of these cancers. In this regard, no effective therapies have emerged from recent clinical trials, which likely reflects the use of a single mouse MPNST model system (Nf1+/-;Trp53+/- mice) and a paucity of human tumor xenografts. To address this critical problem, our laboratories have successfully generated a series of patient-derived MPNST xenografts that more accurately reflect the genetic heterogeneity seen in the human condition. To date, we have generated 15 NF1-MPNST patient-derived xenograft (PDX) lines propagated in immunocompromised mice.  We have demonstrated that these lines harbor the spectrum of genomic alterations that we see in patients with NF1, including germline and somatic NF1 mutations, and subsets with loss of CDKN2A, TP53 mutations, EED/SUZ12 mutations, and numerous copy number changes. We plan to use collagen microtissues generated from the PDX lines in vitro to perform high throughput drug screening, to accelerate identification of efficacious therapeutic combinations.  We will then proceed with in vivo testing of the promising combinations. This proposal brings together four institutions with deep expertise in NF1 research and a non-profit, collaborative research institute, Sage Bionetworks, to develop a truly integrated effort to explore the therapeutic potential of a set of well-vetted drugs for MPNST. 

### Specific Scientific Aims
#### Aim 1: Continue development and characterization of NF1-MPNST PDX lines to maintain the platform for pre-clinical testing.  Our goal is to generate a total of at least 20 unique PDX lines available for use in Aims 2 and 3.
#### Aim 2: Determine the in vitro response to cytotoxic chemotherapy or targeted therapy based on molecular phenotype and computational modeling.  Our goal is to screen all PDX for responses to a set of well vetted candidate drugs and drug combinations using a novel high throughput 3-dimensional tissue culture platform.
#### Aim 3: Determine the in vivo response to cytotoxic chemotherapy or targeted therapy or their combination and identify molecular signatures that are associated with this response.

### Funding

In addition to funding from the Neurofibromatosis Research Initiative, this project was also supported in part through NCI 3U54CA224083-02S1 award to Ramaswamy Govindan, Li Ding, and Shunqiang Li for the Washington University PDX Development and Trial Center.

# Project ID: syn5562324


### Phenotypic screening of anti-NF2 drug candidates as a single agent or in combination using high content assays in merlin-deficient and normal mouse schwann cells

This project was an industry-academia collaboration between Cenix Bioscience and the University of Central Florida. MS01 and MS11 mouse Schwann cells (NF2-/- and NF2 wild-type) were screened with 95 different drugs and vehicle conditions for 48 hours in an 8-point dose response format. The screen also included a 30 minute incubation wih 10uM EdU to assess DNA replication in all conditions. At the end of the incubation period, phenotypic measurements were performed with an automated microscope (Image Express) and analyzed with the Definiens automated image analysis software. A variety of nuclear phenotypes were assessed for all conditions, including EDU-positive nuclei, number of nuclei, oversized nuclei, mitotic nuclei, undersized nuclei, non-ellipsoid nuclei, and condensed nuclei. MS11 were Mouse Schwann cells purchased from ScienCell (#M1700). MS01 were derived from Schwann cells from the sciatic nerves of adult Nf2flox2/flox2 mice that underwent Nf2 exon 2 deletion by in vitro infection with a Cre-expressing adenovirus (Ad-Cre).

### Data
Available [here.](syn5562327)

# Project ID: syn22392179

## Description

Established cell lines have been extensively used in Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors (MPNST) research and are a vital tool for basic and preclinical works. However, the most widely used MPNST cell lines had not been exhaustively described and characterized at the genomic and epigenomic level, and for some of them, even the mutational status of critical genes for MPNST-genesis was missing. 

In this project by the [Hereditary Cancer Laboratory](https://www.germanstrias.org/en/research/cancer/10/hereditary-cancer), at the [Germans Trias i Pujol Research Institute (IGTP)](http://www.igtp.cat) in Spain, we performed a deep genomic characterization of 8 of the most widely used MPNST cell lines to provide a solid foundation for MPNST basic and preclinical research. However, along the way, we found that some of the cell lines labeled as MPNST seemed to be derived from other tumor types. We found genomic evidence of this potential misdiagnosis and it perfectly matched with the potential misdiagnoses identified by a methylation-based sarcoma classifier.

This project was published in a paper titled "[Deep genomic analysis of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cell lines challenges current malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor diagnosis](https://www.cell.com/iscience/fulltext/S2589-0042(23)00173-6)" in iScience in 2023 with DOI [10.1016/j.isci.2023.106096](10.1016/j.isci.2023.106096) and previously in a BioRxiv preprint at [https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.05.07.491026v1](https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.05.07.491026v1).

This page contains all data generated in the project, including the raw data from the different genomic experiments (WGS, WES, SNP-array and Methylation arrays) as well as access to the summary information sheets we have generated for each cell line.

### Citation

If you are using the data contained here you should cite MagallÃ³n-Lorenz _et. al._, 2023 at DOI [10.1016/j.isci.2023.106096](10.1016/j.isci.2023.106096)

### Summary information sheets

For each of the cell lines analysed we created a summary information sheet summarizing the global genomic profile, the mutational status of MPNST-related genes, the STR profile, the methylome-based classification, ploidy analysis by flow cytometry, cell culture images and any additional information and mutations.

# Project ID: syn11672851

### Project Summary
${image?fileName=Screen Shot 2018%2D02%2D19 at 4%2E46%2E36 PM%2Epng&align=Right&scale=50&responsive=true}

Phenotypic high-throughput screens are often utilized in modern oncology drug discovery pipelines. Such screens are conducted with an array of molecules (panels of oncology drugs, drugs for other indications, and compounds with possibly unknown bioactivity), ultimately measuring a biological change within a disease model. While these screens can yield valuable hits, they also present the challenge of identifying the target(s) that mediate the effect seen in the screen for several reasons. For example, many drugs have a polypharmacologic target profile making it hard to identify which targets are biologically relevant for a given drug. Furthermore, some libraries contain molecules for which drug-target studies have never been conducted. 
 
To address these challenges, we developed an application that enables exploration of the chemical-biological interaction space. Drug-target interaction data from [ChEMBL](https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chembl/) (CC BY-SA 3.0), [ChemicalProbes.org](www.chemicalprobes.org) (CC BY-SA 3.0), [DGIdb](http://www.dgidb.org/) (open), [DrugBank](https://www.drugbank.ca/) (CC BY-NC 4.0, used with approval), and [Klaeger, et al, 2017](http://science.sciencemag.org/content/358/6367/eaan4368) was collected for over 280,000 molecules. In addition, when quantitative data were obtained, pChEMBL values were calculated. Each molecule was annotated with a name and chemical structure, and every target was annotated with protein & gene identifiers. An interactive web interface was developed using the R Shiny platform and cheminformatics R packages. The app enables the end user with a specific query molecule to search a database of experimentally-derived drug-target interactions. The database can be queried using drug names or structures. A similarity parameter allows the user to expand their search to other structurally related molecules. The structure of the query molecule is compared to every database molecule, and structurally similar molecules and targets are presented in interactive tabular and network-based forms for in-depth exploration. 
 

The app also performs enrichment analysis on the target lists, and allows the user to evaluate structure-activity relationships for drug response data using publicly-available in vitro datasets. Finally, if a user has a target of interest, they can search for molecules that bind that target and explore the resulting data interactively. This app provides a multifunctional platform for exploring chemical space as it relates to biological targets, and may be useful at several steps along the oncology drug development pipeline including target discovery, structure-activity relationship, and lead identification studies.

## 2021 update:

Wow, it's been a while since this project was first released. Some updates: 
- I recently created an R package with functions that allow you to build a database locally. This might be of interest if you have some proprietary drug-target information that you'd like to aggregate alongside public data. Documentation is a work in progress, but please reach out if you'd like help: https://github.com/nf-osi/dtexbuilder
- I've updated to v4 of the database. This database now contains content from ChEMBL v24.1, ChemicalProbes (07-02-2018), DGIdb 3.0.2, DrugBank 5.1.0 to ChEMBL v28, ChemicalProbes.org (03-10-2021), DGIdb 4.2.0, DrugBank 5.1.8.
-this updates deprecates the concept of "internal_id's", and instead relies on the InChIKey to describe unique molecules. There is a small, but nonzero, chance that there are colliding hashed InChIs causing multiple molecules to be mis-aggregated together. However, this is unlikely considering the size of this database (e.g. the molecules in the database are restricted to "real" molecules and of those, only those that have been tested for activity against human targets). More reading on this issue here: https://depth-first.com/articles/2009/04/24/the-first-inchikey-collision/

I've also made some updates to the front end app to make it compatible with the v4 database. I've also tackled some old bugs:
- CIR search no longer works reliably, replaced with PUG-REST pubchem API query
- enrichr data structure had a breaking change that resulted in the gene set enrichment analysis module no longer working. replaced Z-scores (which no longer exist) with combined scores.

# Project ID: syn37861830

# From cold to hot - Reprogramming tumor microenvironment to target NF1 malignancies
## CTF - Young Investigator Award
### Principal Investigator: Bandarigoda Nipunika Somatilaka
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Bandarigoda Nipunika Somatilaka
### Institution: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center
### Project Description:
Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) affects about 1 in 3000 people worldwide. Patients with NF1 often develop benign tumors on the skin and along the nerves in the spinal cord and brain, and about 8-13% of those become cancerous over time. These cancerous tumors are called Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors (MPNST). The only method of curing MPNST is surgical removal, however, these tumors can be large and located close to complex nerve networks, making complete removal difficult. As a result, tumors tend to reappear after surgery or tumor cells migrate to different sites like lung or bone. When complete removal cannot be achieved, radiotherapy and chemotherapy are recommended to manage the tumor. Unfortunately, MPNST respond poorly to both these therapies. With this lack of treatment options, survival of patients with MPNST is low.  NF1 is caused by a mutation of the NF1 gene, which encodes a protein called neurofibromin. Neurofibromin acts as an off-switch for downstream signaling pathways. Therefore, inactivating mutations of the NF1 gene produce non-functional neurofibromin resulting in constant signaling of these pathways. Researchers have tried to target these pathways with various drugs to treat MPNST, however clinical trials testing these drugs against MPNST were not successful. Therefore, finding a druggable target for MPNST has been challenging. Given the difficulty of surgical and clinical management, identifying an effective treatment strategy for MPNST is a desperate need.  A recent approach to treating inoperable, undruggable cancer has been to use Immune Checkpoint Blockers (ICB). The role of immune checkpoints is to prevent the persistence of normal immune responses to avoid possible collateral tissue damage. Cancer cells hijack this mechanism and express immune checkpoint proteins to avoid detection by a patientâ€™s immune cells. ICB disrupts this process, thus enhancing antitumor immunity. ICB has revolutionized the treatments of many cancers. However, for this approach to work, T cells and other types of immune cells must be present in the vicinity and within the tumor. Unfortunately, MPNST are â€œcold tumorsâ€ meaning they do not have many immune cells near and/or within the tumor. This makes using ICB against MPNST challenging.  We hypothesize that turning MPNST into a â€œhotâ€ tumor, i.e. increasing immune cell infiltration into the tumor, will make it susceptible to targeting with ICB. In this proposal, we will use a strategy to increase the number of T cells and other immune cells near and/or within the tumor: we will activate the cGAS-STING-IFN pathway, which enhances antitumor immunity through the production of a variety of small molecules capable of tumor cell destruction. We will treat MPNST-bearing mice with different small-molecule drugs to activate the STING pathway, thus turning the MPNST into â€œhotâ€ tumors. We will then test various combinations of STING-activating drugs and immune checkpoint blockers to determine if they are effective in shrinking MPNST. If successful, this will represent a novel treatment strategy for MPNST, an aggressive and malignant tumor for which no molecular therapy currently exists.

# Project ID: syn4939874

**Initiative:** Cell Culture
**Name:** Peggy Wallace
**Contact Email:** peggyw@mgm.ufl.edu
**Dates:** 6-1-13 to 5-31-16
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Preclinical Translational models
 
**Background & Rationale:** Neurofibromas, which are benign Schwann cell tumors, are the hallmark feature in the autosomal dominant condition neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1) and are associated with biallelic loss of NF1 gene function. There is a need for effective therapies for neurofibromas, particularly the larger, plexiform neurofibromas. Tissue culture is an important tool for research. However, it is difficult to derive enriched human Schwann cell cultures, and most enter replicative senescence after 6â€“10 passages, impeding cell-based research in NF1.  We are well-positioned to develop cellular models, and collaborate with a robotics R&D/Lead Optimization group.
 
**Goals of Project:** To identify (create/characterize) semi-immortalized pNF and normal/heterozygous SC lines with suitable phenotypes, such that these lines can be tested in and transitioned to an HTS environment.
 
**Specific Aims:** 
 (1) To create and characterize (semi)immortal PNF Schwann cell lines and normal /heterozygous Schwann cells and compare to the matched, primary cells
 (2) To identify phenotype(s) and genotype(s) that recapitulate original tumor SCs and distinguishes these from normal and heterozygous SCs
 (3) To work with HTS group in identifying optimal media/single culture conditions, prior to scaling the cell culturing and relevant assays to a high-throughput format
 
**Impact:** Development of critical and much-needed cellular tool-set for the field of NF1
 
**CELLS AVAILABLE FOR ORDERING WITH UP TO 100% REIMBURSEMENT OF PURCHASE BY NTAP! ** 
The cells developed and characterized from this project are NOW AVAILABLE FOR ORDERING from ATCC.  To order cells,  [click here](https://www.atcc.org/search#q=NTAP&sort=relevancy).  Your purchase of these cells is up to 100% REIMBURSABLE  by the Neurofibromatosis Therapeutic Acceleration Program (NTAP)! To learn more about getting a reimbursement for your purchase,  [click here](http://www.n-tap.org/plexiform-neurofibromas/cell-lines/)

# Project ID: syn8016650

##TRAPping the metabolic adaptations of plexiform neurofibroma
**Initiative:** Open
 
**Names:** Giorgio Colombo, Ph.D.; Andrea Rasola, Ph.D., M.S.
**Contact Email:** giorgio.colombo@gmail.com; andrea.rasola@unipd.it
**Dates:** 1/1/2017 to 12/31/2019
**Tumor Focus:** plexiform neurofibromas, MPNST
**Application**:  preclinical, translational
 
**Background:** 
Plexiform neurofibroma (PN) is a complex tumor that develops within perineural sheaths of nerve bundles in neurofibromatosis type I (NF1) patients. Albeit benign, PNs can be disfiguring, can dangerously compress surrounding tissues or undergo transformation into highly aggressive sarcomas termed malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs). PN formation and growth require mutations at the NF1 gene, leading to loss of the Ras GTPase activating protein (Ras-GAP) neurofibromin and to the ensuing induction of the Ras/ERK transduction axis. Oncogenic signalling via the Ras/ERK pathway contributes to the metabolic rewiring of tumor cells, a crucial hallmark of neoplastic transformation. In tumor cells changes in mitochondrial activity lead to accumulation of oncometabolites, such as succinate, that prompt neoplastic growth via regulation of transcription factors or epigenetic changes. The role of metabolism in PN formation or in PN transformation into MPNST was never investigated. We have previously shown that in tumor cells the Ras/ERK transduction pathway has a mitochondrial branch, and that the mitochondrial chaperone TRAP1 increases intracellular succinate, thus activating the tumorigenic programs mastered by the transcription factor HIF1. These observations suggest the possibility that hyperactive ERK might target TRAP1 in mitochondria of PN cells, thus leading to succinate-dependent, pro-neoplastic HIF-1 activation. 
 
**Goals of Project:** 
This project aims at investigating the possibility that hyperactive Ras/ERK signalling could contribute to pro-neoplastic metabolic rearrangements in mitochondria of neurofibroma cells by regulating TRAP1 chaperone activity, thus crucially contributing to the processes of growth and malignant transformation of PNs. We will dissect the mode of action of TRAP1, connecting it with the metabolic status of PNs and MPNSTs, which will be thoroughly investigated in in vivo tumor models.
 
**Methods:**
Starting from these premises, we will design allosteric TRAP1 inhibitors to be tested as putative anti-neoplastic compounds on PN and MPNST models. Analysis of structure-dynamics-function relationships for complexes between TRAP1 and nucleotides or small ligands will be carried out in order to achieve a computational characterization of allosteric mechanisms of regulation of TRAP1 chaperone activity, and to find out druggable sites. This information will be translated into pharmacophore models that will be first used to screen drug libraries. Analysis of the efficacy of the selected compounds as TRAP1 allosteric inhibitors will be studied by a stepwise in vitro, in cell and in vivo approach, leading to the use of first generation molecules as leads for the design and synthesis of potentially more powerful derivatives
  
**Impact:**  To gain insight on the mode of action and role of TRAP1, with regards to PN and MPNST metabolism.

# Project ID: syn8016599

##Modeling signaling networks of NF1-deficient Schwann cells and plexiform neurofibromas using mass spectrometry-based proteomics
**Initiative:** Open
 
**Name:** James Walker, Ph.D.
**Contact Email:** jwalker@helix.mgh.harvard.edu 
**Dates:** 12/1/2016 to 11/30/2018
**Tumor Focus:** plexiform neurofibromas
**Application**: preclinical translational, mouse models 
 
**Background:**
Plexiform neurofibromas (PNs) are among the most serious symptoms of NF1. Although benign, they cause signficant morbidity, and a substantial fraction transform into typically fatal malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors. NF1 is caused by loss of neurofibromin, a protein whose best-defined function is to serve as a GTPase Activating Protein (GAP) for Ras. Consequently, loss of neurofibromin can result in misregulation of signaling downstream of Ras, the best documented being the RAF/MEK/ERK and PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathways. Although disregulated Ras signalling is believed to be the proximal cause of NF1 symptoms, it is unclear which of the numerous effectors downstream of Ras are relevant for disease progression, as are the identities of the disease-pertinent targets of the signaling pathways mediating their effects. The situation is further complicated since there is undoubtedly cross-talk between these different pathways. Despite considerable effort, no effective therapy for Ras-driven cancers has yet emerged. Furthermore, it is clear that neurofibromin has other functions that likely play a role in clinical outcomes as well. This has motivated our work to find the precise pathways that are responsible for NF1 symptoms, in the hope that this will allow better-targeted therapy. 
  
**Goals of Project:**
We aim to identify putative proteomic and/or phosphoproteomic signatures associated with loss of NF1. Recent advances in mass-spectrometry (MS)-based proteomics permit the determination of the extent, localization, and site-specific stoichiometry of protein phosphorylation. We propose using two complementary MS-based approaches to define (i) the proteome and phosphoproteome and (ii) the activated kinome signature of NF1-deficient Schwann cells (SCs). We will perform analyses on a panel of SC lines derived from PNs. Transcriptome profiling of cell lines will complement these data sets, together providing a detailed view of the cellular signaling networks and the molecular targets controlled by neurofibromin in a cell-type relevant to the disease. Finally, we will use small molecule inhibitors to both known and any novel signaling pathways we identify to examine the adaptive kinome in treated cell lines. Combining the use of a novel panel of cell lines with the sensitivity of high-end MS, we expect to identify signaling pathways and targets previously implicated as being important in NF1-associated tumors, as well as new and unexpected targets downstream of NF1. 
 
**Specific Aims:** 
1) Test cell lines for tumorigenic potential in vivo and optimize growth conditions of cells. For determining the proteomic and kinomic signatures associated with loss of neurofibromin, we will select NF1-deficient cell lines derived from PNs that display tumorigenic potential in vivo. Xenograft assays on PN-derived cell lines in mice will be used to evaluate their tumoigenicity in vivo.
2) Identify phospho-targets misregulated in NF1Â¬-deficient SCs. Multiplexed quantitative mass spectrometry-based phosphoproteomics will be used to quantitatively map phosphorylation level changes across all cell lines. Novel phosphoproteins identified as being misregulated in NF1-deficient cells will be validated using western blotting using available antibodies and also in independently CRISPR-generated NF1-deficient cell lines that we have available.	
3) Analysis of kinome signatures of NF1-deficient SCs using Multiplexed Inhibitor Beads (MIBs) and MS analysis. Knowledge of the relative expression and activation status of the kinome of NF1-deficient cells will enable a comprehensive understanding of the signaling pathways controlled by neurofibromin and mechanisms underlying any phosphoproteome changes. Transcriptome profiling of kinases using RNAseq will enable both the global kinome signature and PTMs to be assessed relative to changes in gene expression. The main focus of our attention will be on using the MIB/MS technique to define the kinome response signature of NF1-deficient SCs to selected inhibitors that are currently in pre-clinical and clinical testing for NF1. 
4) Create a network linking altered phosphorylation events with relative level of activated kinases caused by loss of NF1. The comprehensive set of molecular data consisting of gene expression (RNAseq), global protein levels (total proteome) and protein modifications/function (phosphoproteome/kinome) for each of the cell lines (with appropriate NF1+/+ and NF1+/- controls) will enable us to focus our attention on a common signaling pathway, gene target or group of genes that have altered expression/function in NF1-deficient tumorigenic cells. By incorporating kinome data sets obtained from treating NF1Â¬-deficient SC cell lines with small molecule inhibitors we will be able to define the adaptive kinome response (â€˜reprogrammingâ€™) in NF1Â¬-deficient SCs upon drug therapies for PNs. 
 
**Impact:** The datasets and systems analyses described will be made publically available at SAGE/Synapse and will provide a wealth of hypotheses and opportunities for the NF1 research community to gain a better understanding of the fundamental mechanisms involved in NF1-regulated signaling and plexiform neurofibroma development.

# Project ID: syn4939910

##Targeting the mechanisms underlying cutaneous neurofibroma formation in NF1: a clinical translational approach
**Initiative:** Francis Collins
 
**Name:** Matthew R. Steensma, M.D.
**Contact Email:** Steensma@Spectrumhealth.org
**Dates:** 7-1-15 to 5-31-17
**Tumor Focus:** plexiform neurofibroma, MPNST
**Application:** Imaging Biomarkers (omics data)
 
**Background:** 
Cutaneous neurofibromas (CNFs) are ubiquitously expressed in Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) patients. They are one of three cutaneous diagnostic criteria in addition to cafÃ©-au-lait spots and axillary freckling. They can be distinguished from other cutaneous manifestations of NF1 based on their size (0.5-3cm), sessile or polypoid morphology, and typical lack of pigment. CNFs account for substantial morbidity and disfigurement in NF1. Unlike plexiform neurofibromas, which are congenital lesions, CNFs manifest during adolescence suggesting that their pathogenesis is influenced by environmental or hormonal factors. CNFs are comprised of a confederacy of cell types with distinct embryonic lineages, including Schwann-like cells, perineural cells (neural crest or neuro-ectoderm), fibroblasts (mesoderm), and mast cells (bone marrow-derived).
 
CNFâ€™s cause significant morbidity  and disfigurement in Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1). They bear histologic similarity to Plexiform Neurofibromas (PNFs), however they lack malignant potential, exhibit a less aggressive growth pattern, and arise during adolescence as opposed to being congenital lesions like PNFs. These clinical observations suggest that CNF molecular pathogenesis differs from that of PNFs. To further contrast the verified differences in peripheral nerve tumors, MPNSTs are verified to be highly aggressive sarcomas that do not respond to chemotherapy.  
 
**Goals of Project:** To develop new therapy strategies for peripheral nerve sheath tumors associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1: Cutaneous Neurofibromas (CNFs) and Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors (MPNSTs).  
 
**Specific Aims:** 
1. To demonstrate that CNFs maintain a unique, targetable genomic profile that is distinct from that of PNFs, and varies based on the stage of CNF development (incipient versus established lesions).
2. Address a current gap in knowledge in cNF pathophysiology by performing detailed histologic and pathoanatomic analysis of clinical cNF specimens.
3. Leverage existing models of PN tumor initiation from secondary project to generate high quality preclinical data to support PN tumor therapy trials.
 
**Methods:**
Our first research project is to determine whether targetable epigenetic alterations exist between CNFs and PNFs. We designed a surgical trial to collect highly annotated CNF tissues at various stages of disease progression. We recently completed a large epigenetic profiling study comparing harvested CNF tissues with matched, tissue-Â­â€type controls to PNFs and MPNSTs. These data are currently being analyzed. Our secondary trial objective was to define the surgical anatomy of CNFs in comparison to other types of neurofibromas that involve the dermis. 
 
  Our second research project addresses the hypothesis that Ras and non Ras-Â­â€dependent kinase signaling drives disease progression and therapy resistance in NF1-Â­â€related MPNSTs, and that putative MPNST genomic alterations influence cellular adaptation to tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) treatment. This hypothesis is based on preliminary data where we determined the sequence of genomic alterations that occurred in a case of MPNST progression from a PNF. Various treatment timepoints are shown (below):
${previewattachment?fileName=NTAP Summary Steensma 2%2C Figure 1%2Ejpg}
 
The earliest genomic alterations observed were MET, HGF and EGFR copy number gains. Our subsequent in vitro and in vivo modeling experiments verified the importance of RAS-Â­â€MET signal interaction not only in malignant transformation but also therapy response to MET inhibition. We employ a novel, genetically engineered NF mouse model featuring MET overexpression in myelinating peripheral nerve cells to show that the highly selective MET inhibitor, capmatinib, has exquisite activity in MET-Â­â€addicted murine MPNSTs (below).
${previewattachment?fileName=NTAP Summary Steensma 2%2CFigure 2%2Ejpg}  
 
**Impact:**  Innovative and highly translational approach to defining the pathophysiology of CNF initiation and progression, such that unique and novel preventive and/or treatment strategies for NF1 can be developed. 
 
**Publications:** 
* Steensma M.  Enhanced MET signaling drives malignant tumorigenesis in a mouse model of Neurofibromatosis Type 1. (submitted)

# Project ID: syn11374353

###Identification of pathways triggered by Schwann cell-fibroblast interactions driving cutaneous neurofibroma growth

 

#####**PI:**  Eduard Serra

 

######**Background and Study Design:**  

Cutaneous neurofibromas (cNF) are benign tumors of the peripheral nerves present in almost all neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) patients. cNFs are composed of different cell types, mainly Schwann cells (SCs) and fibroblasts (FBs). Inactivation of the NF1 gene in SCs is believed to be the cause triggering cNF formation. Extensive analysis has shown that from a genetic and genomic perspective, there is no additional recurrent genetic alteration besides the NF1 inactivation involved in cNFs. Despite its simple genetic etiology, the contribution of the interactions among cells composing cNFs need to be investigated to better understand their role in cNF formation and their potential influence on treatment response. In this work, we propose to use co-cultures of cNF-derived primary SCs and FBs to identify expression signatures in cNFs that are specifically due to SC-FB heterotypic interactions. For this purpose we will compare RNA-Seq data from cNFs, their single cell primary cultures and co-cultures of SCs and FBs. Furthermore, we will identify the genetic variation present in gene coding regions of neurofibroma donors. Since SCs and FBs used in co-cultures will belong to different individuals, we estimate to dissect about 75% of the expression signature due to SC-FB interactions by assigning each differently expressed gene to a specific cell type, according to their genetic variation. Signaling pathways represented by expression signatures will be analyzed and their disruption tested functionally.

 

######**Deliverables:**

Obtain an expression signature of cNFs specifically due to SC-FB interactions. Dissect from this signature which genes are expressed in SCs and which in FBs. Identify from signatures SC-FB specific signaling pathways. Test the functional impact of their disruption.

 

######**Expected Outcomes:**

Understand the signaling between SCs and FBs within cNFs and their importance and impact on their viability, proliferation capacity and contribution to cNF development.

 

######**Challenges and Gaps:**

cNFs are not only composed by SCs and FBs. Probably interaction with mast cells and other cell types play their role in cNF formation. The present work is only focused in the interaction of the two main cell types present in cNFs.

# Project ID: syn21650484


##Stem cell derived RGCs: Improving the success of transplantation strategies

##VRI Subgroup: 
Exogenous RGC Replacement

##Principal Investigators: 
Michael Young, PhD (Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary)
Petr Baranov, MD, PhD (Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary)

##Personnel:
Petr Baranov, MD, PhD (PI)

##Lay Abstract

Our overall goal is to improve the success of RGC transplantation, using mouse cells, together with tissue engineering and pig to pig transplantation studies.  We will first identify and optimize key variables using mouse cells that can be applied for pig, non-human primate and human retinal ganglion cell precursors. The premise is that the development of RGCs from stem cells is conserved and the cues we identify may be relevant for all RGCs.  Testing them in mouse has two key advantages:  The timeframe for differentiation is much shorter, which allows one to test more variables; and the mouse model allows for mouse to mouse (allograft) studies which is a likely therapeutic strategy in humans. We have shown that mouse stem cells-derived RGCs are diverse, functional and integrate into healthy and RGC-depleted retinas following injection into the chamber of the eye in front of the retina. We have also demonstrated long-term survival and growth of processes into the optic nerve.   We have three sub-aims for this approach:  1 ) Identifying the stage of differentiation with the highest potential for transplantation 2. Evaluate different types of RGCs for transplantation studies 3.  Improving RGC maturation in retinal tissue, differentiated from stem cells. We will work closely with team members to develop appropriate differentiation (DZ) and transplantation (JG) protocols. 
We will also develop novel tissue engineered transplants aimed at improving graft success.  Using cells and protocols from Aim 1, we will develop polymer composite grafts capable of improving survival, engraftment, and differentiation of transplanted RGCs.  Cells from JG and DZ, along with cells from Aim 1 will be used for these studies.   Lastly, building upon studies by team members using mouse and human RGCs, we will develop pig RGCs for the purpose of performing pig-pig allograft (same species) studies in disease models.  Human and mouse protocols from DZ and PB will be used to generate pig RGCs.

# Project ID: syn7231973

##Perpetuating NF1+/- and NF1-/- plexiform neurofibroma-derived tumor cells  through the generation of induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells
**Initiative:** Cell Culture
 
**Name:** Eduard Serra, Ph.D.
**Contact Email:** eserra@igtp.cat
**Dates:** 5-1-13 to 8-31-15
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Preclinical Translational models
 
**Background:** Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) associated neurofibromas are benign tumors of the peripheral nerves that are difficult to study due to their heterogeneous cellular composition and their genetic heterogeneity regarding the NF1 mutational status of the different cell types. Plexiform neurofibromas (pNFs) differ from discrete neurofibromas (dNFs) in their moment of appearance (though to be congenital in pNFs), the importance of the extension of the nerve and tissues affected (larger in pNFs) and their potential to progress to malignancy, not present in dNFs. Regarding genomics and transcriptomics, Schwann cells (SC) derived from dNFs and pNFs are very much alike. So what is different among these tumors that confer pNFs a risk to become malignant? The extent of affected tissue? The location? The temporal window at which a neural crest-derived cell committed to the SC lineage acquires a double inactivation of the NF1 gene? A particular cellular composition? A combination of factors?
 
**Goals and Specific Aims:**
*  Explore the degree of genomic, molecular and cellular variation within a whole plexiform neurofibroma (pNF).
*  Obtain, authenticate and characterize NF1-/- and NF1+/- induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) derived from pNFs.
 
**Publications:** a manuscript describing this work is currently in progress.

# Project ID: syn23651229

# Ultra-low-pass whole genome sequencing of plasma cfDNA from patients with plexiform neurofibroma and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors. 

#### **Principal Investigators:** Jack Shern, MD,  Angela Hirbe, MD/PhD and Aadel Chaudhuri, MD/PhD
#### **Project Lead / Data Coordinator:** R. Taylor Sundby, MD and Jeff Szymanski, MD/PhD
#### **Institution:** National Cancer Institute - Pediatric Oncology Branch and Washington University in St Louis

#### **Project Description**
The leading cause of mortality for patients with the neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) cancer predisposition syndrome is the development of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST), an aggressive soft tissue sarcoma. In the setting of NF1, this cancer type frequently
arises from within its common and benign precursor, plexiform neurofibroma (PN). Transformation from PN to MPNST is challenging to diagnose due to difficulties in distinguishing cross-sectional imaging results and intralesional heterogeneity resulting in biopsy sampling errors. This multi-institutional study from the National Cancer Institute and Washington University in St. Louis used fragment size analysis and ultra-low-pass whole genome sequencing (ULP-WGS) of plasma cell-free DNA (cfDNA) to distinguish between MPNST and PN in patients with NF1. Results and analysis are published  in "Cell-free DNA ultra-low-pass whole genome sequencing to distinguish malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) from its benign precursor lesion: A cross-sectional study" (https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1003734).

# Project ID: syn18904024

PROJECT TITLE: Optical dopamine monitoring with dLight1 reveals mesolimbic phenotypes in a mouse model of neurofibromatosis type 1.

AUTHORS: J. Elliott Robinson^1^, Gerard M. Coughlin^1^, Acacia M. Hori^1^, Elisha D. Mackey^1^, Jounhong Ryan Cho^1^, Zeynep Turan^1^, Tommaso Patriarchi^2^, Lin Tian^2^, and Viviana Gradinaru*^1^

AFFILIATIONS:
^1^Division of Biology and Biological Engineering, California Institute of Technology, 1200 E California Blvd, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA
^2^Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Medicine, University of California, Davis, One Shield Ave, Davis, CA 95616, USA

ABSTRACT: 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is an autosomal dominant disorder whose neurodevelopmental symptoms include impaired executive function, attention, and spatial learning that could be due to perturbed mesolimbic dopaminergic circuitry. However, these circuits have never been directly assayed in vivo. We employed the genetically encoded optical dopamine sensor dLight1 to monitor dopaminergic neurotransmission in the ventral striatum of NF1 mice during motivated behavior. Additionally, we developed novel systemic AAV vectors to facilitate morphological reconstruction of dopaminergic populations in cleared tissue. We found that NF1 mice exhibit -reduced spontaneous dopaminergic neurotransmission that was associated with excitation/inhibition imbalance in the ventral tegmental area and abnormal neuronal morphology. NF1 mice also had more robust dopaminergic and behavioral responses to salient visual stimuli, which were stimulus-dependent, independent of learning, and rescued by optogenetic inhibition of GABAergic neurons in the VTA. Overall, these studies provide a first in vivo characterization of dopaminergic circuit function in the context of NF1 and reveal novel pathophysiological mechanisms. 

FUNDING: National Institutes of Health, Heritage Medical Research Institute, the Tianqiao and Chrissy Chen Institute for Neuroscience, the National Science Foundation, the Children's Tumor Foundation, and the National Science and Engineering Research Council of Canada

# Project ID: syn22267284

## **Mapping and Identifying the Roles of Protein Glycosylation in Neurofibromatosis 1**

### CTF Young Investigator:
#### Kevin Bruemmer

### Investigator Institution:
Stanford University

### Abstract:
Neurofibromin is a regulator of cancer driver proteins through its functional role as a Ras-GTPase activating protein. Upon loss-of-function mutations to neurofibromin, patients develop benign or malignant nerve sheath tumors that lead to the disease neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), affecting 1 in 2,000 people. Due to the complex signaling network of neurofibromin and the cancer-driver pathways it regulates, phosphorylation post-translation modifications have been extensively studied to explain the biological mechanisms for tumor development. Protein glycosylation, specifically N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc), is known to have significant crosstalk with phosphorylation sites in the proteome, but has never been studied in the context of a living model system for potential regulation and contribution to the pathogenesis of NF1. To better characterize glycosylation changes at various stages of NF1 malignancies, this proposal aims to develop three complimentary chemical biology approaches to create tools for the understanding of protein GlcNAcylation in cellular model systems of NF1 and MPNSTs. We will use glycoproteomics to investigate how loss of neurofibromin affects O-GlcNAc incorporation in the proteome to reveal key sites of biological regulation affected by the Ras cancer driver pathway. We will also perform protein engineering on a N-acetylglucosamine transferase V (GnT-V), known to be overexpressed in malignant tumors, to identify protein substrates in non-malignant and malignant Schwann cells. Revealing the substrate scope of GnT-V will allow the identification of biological pathways that are aberrant in malignant nerve cells due to increased glycosylation at specific glycosites. We will also biochemically investigate glycosylation marks directly on neurofibromin, to give a clearer picture of how post-translational modifications affect the interaction of neurofibromin with cancer driver proteins and affect neurofibromin localization.
