# Project ID: syn4939878

##Development of a Child Neurofibromatosis Type 1 Health Related Quality of Life Measure
**Initiative:** Patient Reported Outcome (PRO) 
 
**Name:** Nancy Swigonski, MD, MPH (Principal Investigator)
**Name:** Kavitha Nutakki, MBBS, MPH (Project Manager)
**Contact Email:** knutakki@iupui.edu
**Dates:** 2-1-14 to 1-31-17
**Tumor Focus:** plexiform neurofibroma
**Disease Focus:** Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1)
**Application**: Clinical Endpoint Tool
 
**Goals of Project:** To develop and test the feasibility, reliability and validity of the child self-report and parent proxy-report versions of the Pediatric Quality of Life InventoryTM (PedsQLTM) NF1 module.
 
**Aims:** To develop and test the measurement properties of the Pediatric Quality of Life InventoryTM (PedsQLTM) Neurofibromatosis Type 1 Module for pediatric patients ages 5-25 with NF1 from the perspectives of patients and parents.
 
**Impact**: The PedsQLTM NF1 Module Scales demonstrated acceptable to excellent measurement properties, and may be utilized as standardized metrics to assess NF1-specific symptoms and problems in clinical research and practice in children, adolescents, and young adults. The PedsQLâ„¢ NF1 Module will have a significant impact on the design of clinical trials targeted to better understand and improve clinical treatment for NF1. 
 
**Publications**:  
1.	Nutakki K, Varni JW, Steinbrenner S, Draucker CB, Swigonski NL. Development of the pediatric quality of life inventory neurofibromatosis type 1 module items for children, adolescents and young adults: qualitative methods. J Neurooncol. 2017 Mar;132(1):135-143. doi: 10.1007/s11060-016-2351-2. Epub 2017 Jan 11. PubMed PMID: 28078640, http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11060-016-2351-2 
 
2.	Draucker CB, Nutakki K, Varni JW, Swigonski NL. The health-related quality of life of children, adolescents, and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and their families: Analysis of narratives. J Spec Pediatr Nurs. 2017 Feb 15. doi: 10.1111/jspn.12174. [Epub ahead of print] PubMed PMID: 28198162, http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jspn.12174/abstract

# Project ID: syn11681835

###Novel Therapeutics in Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor (MPNST)

 

#####**PI:**  Ping Chi, MD, PhD
**Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center **

 

######**Background:**  

Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor (MPNST) arising from the cellular component of the peripheral nerves represents a group of highly aggressive soft tissue sarcomas with limited treatment options. They can occur in the setting of type I neurofibromatosis (NF1-associated), or sporadically or in association with prior radiotherapy (RT-associated). Using comprehensive genomic approaches, we and others have discovered that the majority of MPNSTs have inactivation of three tumor suppressor pathways, including the NF1, the CDKN2A (INK4A/ARF) and the Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) pathways. Here, we propose to use multidisciplinary approaches to establish authentic MPNST model systems for preclinical investigation. We will also evaluate a combination treatment strategy of trametinib (a MEK inhibitor) and ribociclib (a CDK4/6 inhibitor) in various cell line and animal models of MPNST. Lastly, we will conduct a screen using RNA interference technology to identify and characterize the genes that are important for MPNST growth and survival when the PRC2 pathway is inactivated. These studies will build important resources for the NF1-research community and can identify novel treatment strategies and streamline clinical therapeutic development for patients with NF1-associated MPNSTs. 

 

######**Technical Study Design:**  

MPNST arising from peripheral nerves represents a group of highly aggressive soft tissue sarcomas with limited treatment options. Using comprehensive genomic approaches, we and others recently discovered concurrent inactivating mutations of the Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) core components (EED or SUZ12), CDKN2A, and NF1. The highly recurrent and specific inactivation of PRC2, NF1 and CDKN2A, posits their critical and potentially cooperative roles in MPNST pathogenesis. MPNSTs with PRC2 loss showed complete loss of H3K27me3 and aberrant transcriptional activation of multiple PRC2-repressed homeobox master regulators and their regulated developmental pathways. Interestingly, Both PRC2-loss and PRC2-wild type MPNSTs and plexiform neurofibromas express high levels of ETV1 and are dependent on ETV1 for cell growth and survival and tumorigenesis. ETV1 and NF1 loss cooperates in MPNST oncogenesis. Here, we propose to build authentic in vitro and in vivo PDX and GEM MPNST modes, evaluate the combination strategy of MEK and CDK4/6 inhibitors to target NF1 loss-ETV1 cooperation and CDKN2A loss in preclinical models, and   investigate the therapeutic vulnerability of PRC2 loss using a non-biased RNAi based screen and subsequent validation. This proposal employs multidisciplinary integrative approaches and leverages the expertise of team of mentors and the sarcoma DMT. These studies will establish important resources for NF1-research, and provide of novel combination strategies in targeting transcriptional dysregulation with near-term translation potential in MPNST therapeutics. They will also provide mechanistic and therapeutic insights of PRC2 loss involved in MPNST tumorigenesis, which may apply to other cancer types with PRC2 functional loss.

 

######**Hypothesis and Deliverables:**

MPNSTs represent a group of highly aggressive soft tissue sarcomas that may occur in distinct clinical settings: NF1-associated, sporadic or radiotherapy (RT)-associated. Using comprehensive and integrative genomic approaches, we have identified recurrent loss of function genetic alterations of three central pathways: Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2, 80%) core components (EED or SUZ12), CDKN2A (81%) and NF1 (>70% of non-NF1-associated) in all MPNSTs, and the three components significantly co-occur1-3. **_These data suggest_** that, despite the clinical and histological heterogeneity, the NF1-associated, sporadic and RT-associated MPNSTs represent a relatively homogeneous group of disease at the molecular level. We demonstrated that MPNSTs with complete PRC2 loss showed complete loss of H3K27me3 and aberrant transcriptional activation of multiple PRC2-repressed homeobox master regulators and their regulated developmental pathways. Introduction of the PRC2 component in a PRC2-deficient MPNST cell line restored H3K27me3 and decreased cell growth. The highly recurrent and specific inactivation of PRC2, NF1 and CDKN2A posits their critical and potentially cooperative roles in MPNST pathogenesis3. Using H3K27me3 IHC based clinical assay, we and others have confirmed loss of H3K27me3 staining indicative of PRC2 loss in ~ 60-70% of high grade NF1-associated MPNSTs4,5. Moreover, H3K27me3 IHC staining is universally intact in neurofibromas including plexiform neurofibromas, but >60% NF1-associated MPNSTs have lost H3K27m3 IHC staining, suggesting that the PRC2 loss is a critical and recurrent event in malignant transformation from benign neurofibroma to MPNST, which likely dictate the clinical behavior and therapeutic responses.  

 

**_Based on these observations, we hypothesize_** that the frequent and concurrent CDKN2A loss and NF1 loss, as well as PRC2 loss in NF1-associated MPNSTs may create therapeutic opportunities for novel therapeutics development and H3K27me3 IHC may represent a novel therapeutic biomarker in MPNST that specifically target PRC2 loss. 

 

Here, **_we propose_** a focused investigation of specific aims centered on creating authentic model systems for novel therapeutic development to target the recurrent genetic alterations encompassing NF1, CDKN2A and PRC2 loss in NF1-associated MPNST. Given the molecular homogeneity, **_these studies will also provide_** us with the molecular underpinnings of therapeutic vulnerabilities of PRC2 loss in all MPNSTs, and shall facilitate therapeutic development for this difficult disease and other tumors that are dependent on PRC2 functional loss.

# Project ID: syn26238842

# Signaling pathways regulated by nitrated proteins as novel therapeutic targets for neurofibromatosis type 2
## CTF Young Investigator Award

### Principal Investigator: Maria C. Franco
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Maria C. Franco,  Isabelle E. Logan
### Institution: Oregon State University, University of Central Florida

### Project Description:
Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a genetic disorder caused by inactivating mutations in the gene encoding the tumor suppressor merlin. NF2 patients develop schwannomas, meningiomas, and ependymomas throughout their life. NF2 patients have few therapeutic options; given the chronic and recurring nature of NF2, careful monitoring and resection radio surgery remains the treatment of choice. Further understanding the drivers of cell proliferation in NF2 and identifying new potential therapeutic targets remains paramount to improve the selectivity of drugs intended for the treatment of these chronic, recurrent tumors. Our group made a fundamental discovery: production of the powerful oxidant peroxynitrite and subsequent tyrosine (Tyr) nitration, an oxidative modification to proteins that occurs in pathological conditions, are essential for NF2 schwannoma cell survival. Excitingly, protein Tyr nitration is very low or absent in healthy cells. Our published and preliminary data posit nitrated proteins as a new category of tumor-directed targets for the development of tumor-directed therapies. We are determined to identify the role of nitrated proteins in the pathogenesis of NF2 and propose Tyr nitrated proteins are a novel therapeutic target. We have identified a number of proteins that are endogenously nitrated in vestibular schwannomas (VS) from NF2 patients. Six of these nitrated proteins are directly involved in signaling pathways dysregulated by the loss of merlin: Galectin 1 (Gal-1), Ras homolog family member A (RhoA), RhoC, Ras related protein 35, 14-3-3, Vimentin and Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90). We discovered that nitrated Hsp90 supports schwannoma cell survival through a gain-of-function, but we also discovered that Hsp90 is not the only nitrated protein with pro-tumorigenic functions, and these other players remain unidentified. Therefore, the goals of the project are to 1) determine the regulation of signaling pathways by Tyr nitration in general, and Tyr nitrated Hsp90 in particular; and 2) identify the specific nitrated protein(s) that support NF2 tumor cell survival, providing a wealth of novel information and opening the door to the development of new therapies for NF2 treatment.

# Project ID: syn11374354

###A 3D Cutaneous Neurofibroma Model for Automated High-Throughput Drug Screenings
 
####**PI:**  Alice Soragni
**[Soragni Lab at UCLA](http://www.soragnilab.com/)**
####**cNF Organoid Project**  
Given the absence of therapeutic options and the heterogeneous nature of cutaneous neurofibromas (cNF), a physiological system that supports the growth of cNF tumor cells is required for drug screening efforts. To date, surgical removal or laser desiccation are the only treatment options, but can result in scarring and the leave a potential for regrowth.
To support drug discovery efforts focused on identifying effective systemic therapies for cNF, we introduce an approach to routinely establish and screen cNF tumor organoids. We optimized conditions to support ex vivo growth of genomically-diverse cNFs. Patient-derived cNF organoids closely recapitulate the molecular and cellular heterogeneity of these tumors as measured by immunohistopathology, DNA methylation, RNA-seq and flow cytometry. Lastly, we have adapted our high-throughput 3D mini-ring approach to screen cNF organoids. Our tractable patient-derived cNF organoid platform enables rapid screening of hundreds of compounds in a patient- and tumor-specific manner.

#### Manuscript
${buttonlink?text=Link to our published paper&url=https://www.cell.com/cell-reports-methods/fulltext/S2667-2375(24)00116-4&highlight=true&align=None}

All data files, results,  and associated metadata (that align with NF Data portal standards) can be programmatically queried, browsed, and downloaded from the [project metadata](syn11601495) table. We included a summary of data below:

# Project ID: syn28545963


${image?fileName=SchwannomatosisOpenResearchCollaborativeBanner%2DV1%2DR1%2D4x%2Epng&align=Center&scale=100&responsive=true&altText=}
# Welcome!
**Schwannomatosis** (SWN) is a rare, understudied genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to the development of nerve sheath tumors. While SWN is in some cases caused by germline mutations in the SMARCB1 and LZTR1 genes, the genomic landscape and genetic modifiers of this disorder are poorly understood. Recent efforts to study the genomics of SWN patients have increased our understanding of the disorder, and much of the data from this research is now publicly available. With support from the Children's Tumor Foundation, we have developed the **Schwannomatosis Open Research Collaborative (SORC)**, a community-based research project with the goal of utilizing public data to uncover new scientific insights into SWN.

#  Objectives

The primary objective of this project is to perform comprehensive genomic analyses to uncover **noncoding variants**, **coding variants in under-studied genes**, or other genomic features that contribute to disease etiology and heterogeneity in SWN, including SMARCB1-related SWN, LZTR1-SWN, 22q-related SWN, SWN-not otherwise specified, and NF2-related SWN. Our secondary objective is to expand the NF communityâ€™s capacity for computational research.

#  Apply for a SORC Computational Partnership to get help analyzing your SWN data
**UPDATE MARCH 2024:** We are excited to launch the **SORC Computational Partnership Initiative**, in which we will work with selected researchers to design and complete genomic analyses, providing the necessary genomics expertise and computational resources.

**To be eligible for this initiative, applicants must:**
-have data available at the launch of the partnership, either directly from the researcher or through publicly available data repositories
-have a specific question they are trying to answer or an analysis they are trying to perform
-agree to complete a data sharing plan and share data used in the analyses through the [NF data portal](https://nf.synapse.org/) at the conclusion of the project or upon publication of a relevant manuscript
-co-author a [micropublication](https://sagebionetworks.pubpub.org/) describing the partnership effort

Applicants should develop an **outline of the proposed analysis** they are hoping to perform or the biological question they would like to answer using the available data. Interested researchers should set up a meeting with SORC leadership for an informal, preliminary discussion to brainstorm and refine analysis ideas. Upon completion of analyses, SORC will provide a written report with all necessary information that can be included in a relevant publication. Our capacity is limited, so we will prioritize projects based on feasibility which will be evaluated on a first-come first-serve basis. Priority will also be given to projects focused on rarer classifications of SWN.

**To apply:**
Please [email us at nf-osi@sagebionetworks.org](mailto:nf-osi@sagebionetworks.org) with the subject line â€œSORC Computational Partnership Proposalâ€ and provide an **outline of your proposed analysis**. We will then set up an informal meeting to discuss your analysis needs or ideas.


# Available Data and Data Access
${image?fileName=SWNTS%5Fdata%5Fprocessing%5Fschematic%2Epng&align=right&scale=35&responsive=true&altText=}
This project utilizes data from the [Synodos for Schwannomatosis initiative](https://nf.synapse.org/Explore/Studies/DetailsPage?studyId=syn9727752).  We have reprocessed available genomic data using standardized pipelines from [nf-core](https://nf-co.re/).  

Processed data such as variant calls and gene counts are available to project participants
To access the files, a user must:
1. [Create a Synapse account](https://www.synapse.org/#!RegisterAccount:0). 
2. [Take the Synapse certification quiz](https://www.synapse.org/#!Quiz:Certification).
3. [Fill in your user profile](https://www.synapse.org/#!Profile:v/profile). At a minimum, first name, last name, current affiliation and [ORCID](https://orcid.org/) are  required.
4. Processed data files can be found [here](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn9727752/files/). Click on the file you wish to access and then click the ***Request Access*** button.
5. Accept the Terms and Conditions of Use for Synodos Schwannomatosis Data

# Join us! Propose or contribute to an analysis

If you would like to join this collaborative effort, please fill out the registration form linked below. This will insure that you receive proper credit for your contributions in publications and any other materials produced as a result of this project. Contributions to this project should be made through the [GitLab repository](https://gitlab.com/nf-community/swnts/). If you have any other questions about this project or accessing the data, please email [nf-osi@sagebionetworks.org](mailto:nf-osi@sagebionetworks.org).

${buttonlink?text=Registration Form&url=https://docs%2Egoogle%2Ecom/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSd%2DlL6x2ub5LAjbzsK1469KWca6qhSEA24lMUJ%5FQkCxdeSEOA/viewform%3Fusp%3Dsf%5Flink&align=center}


## Analyses

All code and results from project analyses will be maintained through the project [GitLab Repository](https://gitlab.com/nf-community/swnts/). 

### Proposed analyses

Several analyses have already been proposed, and can be found on the [issues](https://gitlab.com/nf-community/swnts/-/issues) GitLab page. Proposed analyses include genome-wide variant interpretation and prioritization, transcript analyses to identify novel splice variants or gene fusions in schwannomas, analyses that integrate multiple data types to identify genes or biological pathways of interest, and machine learning analyses trained on larger cancer datasets in order to identify novel biological processes or disrupted patterns that are important in schwannomatosis.
${image?fileName=SWNTS%5Fproposed%5Fanalyses%2Epng&align=center&scale=35&responsive=true&altText=}

### Ideas for new analyses
If you have an idea for an analysis you would like to see utilizing this data, you can submit that idea to the project [GitLab page](https://gitlab.com/nf-community/swnts/-/issues/new).

# Project ID: syn4939892

##Identification of Neurofibroma Growth and Drug Resistance Pathways
**Initiative:** Open
 
**Name:** Nancy Ratner, Ph.D.
**Contact Email:** nancy.ratner@cchmc.org
**Dates:** 2-1-14 to 1-31-16
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Biomarkers, Omics
 
**Background:** Up to 50%>  of children  with NF1 develop plexiform  neurofibromas  that can cause severe disfigurement  and serious morbidity-- and death when they compress vital organs.  Most plexiform neurofibromas are resistant to chemotherapy and surgical removal is often impossible due to tumor size, location, and nerve integration.  We jo not know why some  human neurofibromas  grow slowly and some rapidly,  nor why some neurofibromas respond to therapy but others do not.  Plexiform neurofibromas grow most aggressively in young children, and an appealing (unproven) idea is that transiently blocking growth of plexiform neurofibromas early in tumor development  will prevent  tumor progression.   Models  to study these critical issues have been lacking.   Our laboratory  has recently  developed  mouse models  that recapitulate  1) slow  and fast growing neurofibromas, and 2) neurofibromas that respond or fail to respond to targeted molecular therapy.   We plan to use new methods in gene expression  analysis to identify molecular  pathways  that correlate with these phenotypes  in mouse models, with verification on human tissues.   We also plan test if early treatment delays or halts neurofibroma formation by administering drugs before tumors develop in a neurofibroma mouse model
 
**Goals of Project:** To identify tumor markers that serve as biomarkers in NF growth and tumors that are resistant to therapy
 
**Impact:** 
The work proposed in Aim 1A is expected to identify biomarkers of slow versus fast growing tumors. For example, we might find that fast growing tumors express a secreted factor predicted to be detected in serum or urine. In addition, we might identify targets which, when blocked, can slow the growth of rapidly growing plexiform neurofibromas. Identified markers can be analyzed in human tissues.  The work proposed in Aim 1B is expected to identify pathways that can be targeted to reduce growth of or kill neurofibroma cells. Thus, if we identify genes with high expression in tumors that fail to respond to a drug, we will co-target that pathway with the given drug (e.g. MEKi). If this succeeds in mice, we will test for expression of the gene/pathway in human tissue samples. Thus, we are defining cells and targets to use in clinical trials of plexiform neurofibroma.
 
**Publications:** We will include the Stat genes in a paper that we are beginning to write now, with our MEK/Stat preclinical therapeutics. We will publish the MEK Resistance story after we carry out the preclinical test which we have planned. We will publish the fast versus slow growing tumors if and when we verify that one or more differentially regulated genes have a role in tumor growth.

# DHART SPORE Project 3 Phase 1 - A High Content Clinical Trial of the MEK Inhibitor Trametinib in Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML)
## NIH-NCI - Developmental and HyperActive Ras Tumor Specialized Programs of Research Excellence
### Principal Investigator: Kevin Shannon, Mignon Loh
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Kevin Shannon, Mignon Loh
### Institution: University of California, San Francisco
### Project Description:
Children with NF1 are predisposed to juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), an aggressive myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) that responds poorly to chemotherapy. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) cures ~50% of patients. Our studies of JMML specimens proved that NF1 functions as a tumor suppressor gene in hematopoietic cells, and provided the first direct evidence of deregulated Ras signaling in primary cancer cells from NF1 patients. These studies support the role of hyperactive Ras signaling in JMML pathogenesis, and our group and other researchers subsequently discovered mutations in NRAS, KRAS, PTPN11, and CBL in JMML patient specimens. Overall, >85% of JMML cases have mutations in one of these genes, including 15-20% with clinical NF1 or mutations in the NF1 gene. Despite the routine use of HSCT, up to 30% of JMML patients progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Consistent with the molecular genetics of JMML, using the Mx1-Cre transgene to inactivate the conditional mutant Nf1flox allele generated by the Parada lab or to express oncogenic KrasG12D or NrasG12D in the hematopoietic compartment induces a JMML-like MPN in mice. Preclinical trials in these accurate GEM models revealed remarkable efficacy of MEK inhibitors. Importantly, however, this, treatment does not eradicate mutant bone marrow cells, but modulates their proliferation and differentiation in vivo. The overall goals of Project 3 are to translate these promising preclinical data in JMML patients though an innovative clinical trial that includes deep molecular analysis.

# Project ID: syn4939918

##Using PNF-derived NF1(+/-) and NF1 (-/-) iPS Cells: Understanding PNF-cell of Origin, First Steps in Malignant Progression and Specific Inhibition of NF1 (-/-) Cell Proliferation
**Initiative:** Open
 
**Name:** Edu Serra 
**Contact Email:** eserra@igtp.cat
**Dates:** 12-1-15 to 5-31-18
**Tumor Focus:** plexiform neurofibroma
**Application:** Cell Culture
 
**Background:** In order to identify effective drugs against plexiform neurofibroma (PNF) formation/ progression we need to test them in the right in vitro and in vivo model systems. This involves, among other things, being able to use large quantities of NF1(+/-) and (-/-) cells closely resembling cells driving PNF formation and growth. PNF-derived NF1(+/-) and (-/-) iPS cells have been generated and can be used to test differentiation protocols towards the Neural Crest (NC) -Schwann cell (SC) lineage. Differentiated cells at different points of this lineage commitment can be characterized and engrafted into the sciatic nerve of nude mice to test their tumor-formation capacity and, in this way, interrogate about the identity of the cells originating PNFs. Two things, the setting up the right in vitro iPSC differentiation conditions towards NC and SC in one side and on the other, the characterization of the different steps of differentiation in the NC-SC lineage, will proportionate the basis for performing future drug screenings for PNFs using iPSC-derived cells.
 
**Goals & Aims:** 
â€¢	To set up in vitro conditions to efficiently differentiate iPS cells into cells of the Neural Crest -Schwann cell lineage. Characterize the methylome and transcriptome of these cells with distinct NF1 genotypes and test their potential engraftment/tumor formation capacity.
â€¢	Generate new iPSC and edit control iPSC with distinct NF1 genotypes to interrogate the presence of epigenetic memory in the PNF-derived iPS cells generated
  
**Publications/Posters/Presentations:** Two manuscripts are being written. 
In one manuscript the intra-PNF variability concerning histology and genomics is described. A correlation between histological and genomic findings is presented. All PNFs used for the iPSC generation were included.
In a second manuscript the generation, characterization and use of the PNF-derived NF1(+/-) and NF1(-/-) cell lines is fully described. These cell lines are being deposited in a stem cell bank to give access to interested NF1 researchers.

# Project ID: syn7239560

##Evotec Drug-Target discovery

This site serves as the landing page for the upload and analysis of the drug target research carried out by [Evotec](https://www.evotec.com/). 

###Compound structures
The structure data for each of the drugs annotated by Evotec can be found in two tables. These include the [supplier-provided structures](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn7239560/wiki/410637) and the [unique structure properties](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn7239560/wiki/410636) computed from KNIME.

###Compound Annotations
This resource contains numerous annotations of compounds.

# Project ID: syn4939906

##Screening (Single Agent MIPEs, combo)

**Initiative:** Cell Culture
 
**Name:** Marc Ferrer, Ph.D. (NCATS)
**Contact Email:** marc.ferrer@nih.gov
**Dates:** 2014-2017 (ongoing)
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Efficacy, potency, and synergy data profiles, as well as pathways and targets
 
**Background:** A lack of cellular model systems was identified as a major gap in pNF therapeutics-focused research when NTAP was launched in 2012. Hence, creating a cell culture initiative was an early priority. While current animal models can faithfully mimic some aspects of pNF (tumor histology, imaging characteristics, natural history), they are based on relatively narrow genetically engineered platforms and are not fully representative of human NF1 diversity. Moreover, the tumors in these models are slow growing (requiring 9-12 months for a single compound efficacy study) and costly. Hence, there is a need for in vivo models that allow more rapid drug screening (particularly when considering possible combinatorial therapies) and a need for in vitro models that allow more facile manipulation of the NF1 gene in order to understand the molecular genomics influencing tumor behavior. 
 
**Goals of Project:** 
To create a panel of cell culture systems that represent pNF complexity and can be utilized to both screen new compounds as well as to identify new therapeutic targets.
 
**Specific Aims:**
1. Single agent screen of the MIPE 4.0 library of approx. 1912 small molecules against 9 different cell-lines (5 NF1 nullizygous, 1 carrier, 2 normal, and 1 control) with diverse modes of action, and the generation of single agent viability results for each cell line to ID ~40 top hits (with highest potency and efficacy)
2. Execution of 6 x 6 screen of the top 40 compounds from initial screening, to elicit 780 combinations, such that the top 72 unique combinations (with preliminary optimal synergism profiles) can be elucidated
3. Execution of 10 x 10 screen of top 72 compounds from 2nd screen, in order to focus on 9 combinations prioritized for validation in mouse NF1-/- primary Schwann cells.
 
**Impact:** The screening studies yielded new data about drugs to be considered for pNF, new tools and guidelines for reproducible, transferable cell culture methodology for pNF and new biologic observations that may lead to unanticipated therapeutic discoveries.
 
${buttonlink?text=Back to the NTAP Data Portal&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Esynapse%2Eorg%2F%23%21Synapse%3Asyn4939478}

**Curation Notes:**
In April 2021, Peggy Wallace, et al., determined that the ipnNF95.11c cell line, distributed by ATCC, is probably a / cell line, not a +/- cell line as was originally thought. Thus, the nf1Genotype annotation on data files for these samples has been altered from +/- to -/-,+/-.

# Project ID: syn53185180

# Translating Basic Research towards Improved Clinical and Therapeutic Approaches
## GFF - Other
### Principal Investigator: Raymond Mattingly
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Raymond Mattingly
### Institution: Wayne State University
### Project Description:
Synergistic Suppression of NF1 Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor Cell Growth in Culture and Orthotopic Xenografts by Combinational Treatment with Statin and Prodrug Farnesyltransferase Inhibitor PAMAM G4 Dendrimers
Summary: Activated RAS proteins drive the proliferation and survival of many human tumors. For example, in type 1 neurofibromatosis (NF1), loss of expression of neurofibromin allows hyper-activation of RAS. Drug treatments to block activated RAS have been long sought as a rational and targeted approach to treating cancer, but numerous obstacles have been discovered. We have designed a combinatorial approach to block the maturation of RAS in cellular models of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) from NF1 patients. The combination of a prodrug farnesyl transferase inhibitor (FTI) that is competitive with the prenyl co-factor of the enzyme plus a low dose of lovastatin to reduce cellular pools of prenyl precursors was effective and selective in blocking the proliferation of NF1 MPNST cells in vitro and in an orthotopic xenograft on the murine sciatic nerve. This approach could also be applicable to other cancers that are driven by activated RAS.

# Project ID: syn20608511

#  Whole Body MRI of NF Patients

### **Principal Investigator / Data Contributors:**  Dr. Wenli Cai ( @wcai ) and Dr. Gordon Harris
### **Institution:** Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH)

### General scientific questions:

Can we identify features of MRIs to diagnose specific tumor types or predict disease progression? Can we improve upon current segmentation algorithms?  

Dataset: 2 image modalities (STIR and T1) from 48 NF1, NF2, and schwannomatosis patients using whole-body magnetic resonance imaging (WB MRI). We'll also provide matching structured clinical data (diagnosis, tumor burden, etc) to facilitate phenotypic analysis of the imaging data.

### Data available: 

- Imaging: 96 stacks (two imaging modalities) from 48 patients with NF1, NF2 or Schwannomatosis. Image stacks are [here](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn20704059). Combined .avis for each stack are also available in the [reports folder](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn20708336).
- Clinical metadata: tumor burden information including tumor type and location, available in clinical reports [here](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn20708336).

### Accessing the data:

Please navigate to ["Accessing the Data"](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn20608511/wiki/595382) and follow the instructions to request access to the data. 

### Quality Assurance of the Data:
We will publish these 50 retrospectively collected WBMRI dataset for volumetric image analysis of whole-body MRI for patients diagnosed with NF, including NF1, NF2, and schwannomatosis. All these patients were scanned at MGH by using the clinical standard operational procedures for a clinical MRI system.  The image quality was examined by the board-certified radiologists. These are real clinical MRI data for longitudinal tracking of NF patients.

# DHART SPORE Project 1 Phase 1 - Molecular, Developmental, and Genetic Evaluation of Plexiform Neurofibromas to Inform Clinical Trials
## NIH-NCI - Developmental and HyperActive Ras Tumor Specialized Programs of Research Excellence
### Principal Investigator: D. Wade Clapp, Jaishri Blakeley, Brigitte Widemann, Lu Le
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: D. Wade Clapp, Jaishri Blakeley, Brigitte Widemann, Lu Le
### Institution: Indiana University; Johns Hopkins University; National Institutes of Health; University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center
### Project Description:
Plexiform neurofibromas (PNs) PNs are complex nerve and soft tissue tumors that affect 25-50% of people with NF1, cause serious lifelong morbidity and mortality due to organ compression, and progress to malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNST) in ~8-13% of patients. Collaborative studies performed by Drs. Clapp and Luis Parada in a genetically engineered mouse (GEM) model of PNs unexpectedly demonstrated a central role of infiltrating Nf1 haploinsufficient bone marrow-derived mast cells in promoting the growth of PN lesions in vivo. These novel data led to a clinical trial administering imatinib mesylate to target aberrant stem cell factor (SCF)/c-kit signaling in the tumor microenvironment, which induced objective clinical responses in a subset of patients. Based on the observation that young children with head, neck, and airway tumors were most likely to have partial tumor regression, Drs. Robertson, Blakeley, Widemann and Michael Fisher are pursuing a registration trial in this patient population. More recently, studies in GEM models informed successful clinical trials of MEK inhibitors to directly inhibit aberrant Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK signaling in PN cells. The objective of Project 1 is to extend these promising data to investigate the developmental, molecular, and pharmacokinetic effects of c-kit and MEK inhibition alone and in combination. Our investigative team will characterize the adaptive responses of PNs to these kinase inhibitors in GEM models and in parallel studies in patients.

# Project ID: syn22268639

## **Understanding the role of purinerigic signaling on tumor formation in a mouse model of Neurofibromatosis Type 1**

### CTF Young Investigator:
#### Jennifer Patritti Cram

### Investigator Institution:
Cincinnati Medical Center

### Abstract:
Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a disorder that affects 1:3,000 individuals worldwide. Loss of function of the neurofibroma gene (NF1) causes over activation of the RAS oncogenic signaling pathway. People with NF1 have an increased risk of developing tumors (neurofibromas), both benign and malignant anywhere along the peripheral nervous system (PNS). Neurofibromas arise from Schwann cells (SCs) and/or Schwann cell precursors (SCP). SCs support axons in the peripheral nervous system (PNS). To date, there is no cure for this disease. Therefore, the purpose of this proposal is to identify potential treatments for NF1 by studying the mechanisms involved in tumor formation. 

To identify potential markers and therapeutic targets for NF1, we performed microarray analysis on human plexiform neurofibromas. We dissociated human neurofibromas and sorted tumor derived cells into SCs (p75+/EGFR-) and SCP tumor-initiating cells (p75+/EGFR+) (p75 marks neural crest cells, SC precursors, and non-myelinating SCs, and EGFR+ marks cells that express the Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor) [Schwann cells are EGFR negative]. The hypothesis behind the cell sorting is that genes expressed in neurofibroma SCP-tumor initiating cells (p75+/EGFR+) more than in differentiated neurofibroma Schwann cells (p75+/EGFR-) contribute to tumor initiation. From this microarray study, we found that a purinergic receptor, P2RY14 expression was increased in SCP-like tumor initiating cells (p75+/EGFR+). Then, we sorted the SCP tumor initiating cells (p75+/EGFR+) into P2RY14 positive or negative (p75+/EGFR+/P2RY14+ or p75+/EGFR+/P2RY14-) and we found that the p75+/EGFR+/P2RY14+ cells show an increased ability to self-renew and form spheres in vitro. These results suggest that tumor initiating cells (p75+/EGFR+) that are P2RY14+ might drive tumor growth.

To test if P2RY14 is tumor promoting in vivo, I bred our genetically engineered neurofibroma mouse model (Nf1 fl/fl DhhCre) to P2RY14 knockout mice (P2RY14-/-). Knocking out P2RY14 in the neurofibroma mice (P2Y14-/-; Nf1 fl/fl DhhCre) increases survival and reduces tumor number. This data demonstrates that P2RY14 is involved in neurofibroma formation and that knockout of this receptor in the neurofibroma mouse model increases survival rate in neurofibroma bearing mice. 

I hypothesize that P2RY14 promotes neurofibroma growth by enhancing tumor cell self-renewal and/or proliferation in vitro and that inhibition of this receptor in vivo will result in a decrease of tumor growth. This hypothesis will be tested by completion of these specific aims:

**Aim 1:** Determine if the P2RY14 receptor is necessary for neurofibroma tumor cell proliferation in vitro. I hypothesize that P2RY14 signaling promotes neurofibroma growth in a cell autonomous way by regulating SCP proliferation and/or self-renewal in vitro. A) To determine if P2RY14 activation affects SCP cell proliferation, I will measure proliferating cell rates in WT and Nf1-/- SCP after addition of UDP (P2RY14 agonist). B) To determine if P2RY14 is necessary for neurofibroma SCP proliferation, I will silence P2RY14 expression in WT and Nf1-/- SCP in vitro using the P2RY14 pharmacological inhibitor and/or short-hairpin RNA (shRNA) and measure the rate of proliferating cells. If a change is found, I will determine if the change is MAPK dependent by monitoring RAS signaling or, determine if the change is P2RY14 dependent by monitoring cAMP levels.

**Aim 2:** Determine if the P2RY14 inhibitor drug can decrease neurofibroma growth. I will perform a drug study to determine if administration of a P2RY14 inhibitor by itself and/or in combination with the MEK inhibitor selumetinib for 7 days decreases cell proliferation, cell death, PKA and/or MAPK signaling. I will read out results by immunohistochemistry in tumor sections. If no change is found then, I will conclude that P2RY14 effects are mainly through tumor initiation. If an effect is seen, I will determine what cell types are involved in this process and increase the duration of the drug treatment to assess tumor size and tumor growth kinetics overtime.

Upon completion of the proposed aims in this grant, I will determine if P2RY14 is necessary for neurofibroma tumor cell proliferation in vitro and test if P2RY14 inhibition by drug delivery has an effect on tumor growth in vivo.

A critical gap in the field are the absence of mechanistic studies on the cause of tumor formation and the limited number of drugs available to treat NF1. Therefore, to fill this critical gap in knowledge, in Aim 1 I propose to determine if P2RY14 is necessary for neurofibroma cell proliferation in vitro. In Aim 2, I propose to determine if a P2RY14 pharmacological inhibitor can decrease neurofibroma growth.

Our results will impact the neurofibroma field not only by defining purinergic signaling mechanisms relevant to neurofibroma development but I will also establish if the P2RY14 inhibitor can be used as a treatment for NF1.

# Project ID: syn32128792

# Genomic landscape of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) 
## NFRI - Genomics of MPNST (GeM) Consortium
### Principal Investigator: David Miller
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Katherine Piculell
### Institution: Boston Children's Hospital
### Project Description:
####  Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is the most common tumor predisposition syndrome, and is associated with an aggressive soft-tissue sarcoma, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours (MPNSTs), the greatest cause of morbidity and mortality in people with NF1. The only potentially curative therapy involves surgery which is not always possible. Even therapy with curative intent is associated with poor overall survival for both sporadic and NF1-related MPNSTs. The development of novel therapies has been largely hindered by a lack of understanding of the molecular events underpinning MPNST pathogenesis. This is a comprehensive multi-omic study of MPNST evolution based on whole genome sequencing and transcriptomic data.  

### PLEASE NOTE: This project links to data stored in EGA, annotated with the NF-OSI metadata dictionary to make this dataset visible in the NF Data Portal.  The data itself _is not available_ on Synapse or the NF Data Portal. You must request permission and access the data on [EGA](https://ega-archive.org/datasets/EGAD00001008608/).

# Project ID: syn22268689

## **Identification and functional characterization of the substrates of LZTR1 (schwannomatosis)**

### CTF Young Investigator:
#### Aram Ko

### Investigator Institution:
Columbia University

### Abstract:
LZTR1 is a substrate adaptor protein of the CUL3 ubiquitin ligase complex whose substrates and cellular functions remain mostly unknown. Our laboratory reported for the first time that human brain tumors harbor somatic mutations of the LZTR1 gene. Later studies revealed that LZTR1 is somatically mutated across many types of human tumors. Furthermore, mutations of LZTR1 were identified as the causal event leading to a significant number of cases of schwannomatosis. Schwannomatosis is a rare form of Neurofibromatosis that has only recently been identified. The genetic disorder affects less than 1 in 40,000 people, and causes the development of schwannomas on cranial, spinal and peripheral nerves. Schwannomas may cause pain that may be hard to manage. Although the causal tumor suppressor role of LZTR1 as genetic basis of schwannomatosis has been firmly established, the mechanism by which loss of the activity of the LZTR1 ubiquitin ligases triggers tumor development remains elusive. Temporally coordinated destruction of key cell regulatory proteins by the Ubiquitin-Proteasome System (UPS) represents an important control mechanism to ensure that specific protein functions are turned off at the right time, in the right compartment, and in a unidirectional fashion. Cullin/Ring/Ligase complexes (CRL) control the proteolysis of many important cell regulators. In humans, there are approximately 200 CRL ligases, each characterized by a different substrate recognition subunit that provides specificity by directly recruiting the substrates. Cullin-3 is the molecular scaffold of a major class of CRLs that use BTB domain proteins as substrate-specific adaptors. Despite their large number, only a handful of BTB domain proteins have well-established substrates and their biological functions are largely unknown. Recently, RAS and Rit1 have been proposed as potential substrates of LZTR1. In the context of this work, it was suggested that LZTR1 may inhibit MAPK pathway by repressing RAS activity, but the mechanism of RAS inhibition remains controversial. Furthermore, the full scope of LZTR1 substrates and cellular functions remain unknown. 

Here, we will elucidate the normal biochemical and biological functions of LZTR1 and substrates and the mechanisms by which LZTR1 suppresses tumor growth. This work will use state of the art proteomics to identify and demonstrate the significance of crucial LZTR1 substrates in the context of cancer cells driven by LZTR1 inactivation. We anticipate that the proteomic-based discovery of new LZTR1 substrates will provide a major advance in our understanding of the links between ubiquitin ligases, tumor suppression and of the pathogenesis of Schwannomatosis and the many sporadic tumors driven by loss-of-function genetic alterations (mutations and deletions) of LZTR1. We postulate that LZTR1 substrates
implement oncogenic functions that are normally restrained by LZTR1-mediated ubiquitin-dependent degradation. The expected overall impact of this innovative grant application is that it will fundamentally advance our mechanistic understanding of the LZTR1 ubiquitin ligase as genetic driver of schwannomatosis and sporadic tumors and lay the foundation for the optimization of new therapeutic strategies in syndromic and sporadic tumors associated with loss-of-function genetic alterations of LZTR1.

### Acknowledgement:
Data was provided by:

**Ko A, Hasanain M, Oh YT, D'Angelo F, Sommer D, Frangaj B, Tran S, Bielle F, Pollo B, Paterra R, Mokhtari K, Soni RK, Peyre M, Eoli M, Papi L, Kalamarides M, Sanson M, Iavarone A, Lasorella A. LZTR1 Mutation Mediates Oncogenesis through Stabilization of EGFR and AXL. Cancer Discov. 2023 Mar 1;13(3):702-723. doi: 10.1158/2159-8290.CD-22-0376. PMID: 36445254.**

# Project ID: syn11374345

###Leveraging human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) to determine the impact of patient-derived NF1 gene mutations on peripheral sensory neuron-driven Schwann cell growth
 

#####**PI:**  David H. Gutmann, MD, PhD
#####**Team:** Corina Anastasaki, PhD, Jason B. Papke, MS, and Morgan E. Freret, MS

**University of Washington**

 

######**Background and Rationale:**  

Cutaneous or dermal neurofibromas (cNFs) represent one of the signature tumor types in individuals with the Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) cancer predisposition syndrome. These benign tumors are composed of neoplastic Schwann cells embedded in a microenvironment containing terminal nerve endings, fibroblasts, mast cells, and macrophages. While caused by loss of NF1 protein function in Schwannian lineage cells, studies in mouse plexiform neurofibroma models have revealed a critical role for non-neoplastic stromal cells (fibroblasts, mast cells, and macrophages) in tumor formation, maintenance, and continued growth. In this regard, inhibition of stromal cell (mast cells, macrophages) function in preclinical genetically-engineered mice resulted in attenuated plexiform neurofibroma growth. In addition to fibroblasts, mast cells, and macrophages, the NF1-deficient Schwann cells in cNFs often grow in proximity to terminal nerve endings. The intimate relationship between neurons and Schwann cells during normal peripheral nervous system development and function raises the intriguing possibility that neurons are important drivers of cNF growth. This notion is supported by recent studies in which the proliferation of myelinating cells in the central nervous system (oligodendrocytes) is regulated by neuronal production of a novel growth factor (neuroligin-3). Based on these provocative findings, **we hypothesize that peripheral sensory neurons accelerate NF1-deficient Schwann cell growth through the elaboration of mitogens.** To identify these potentially clinically-actionable mitogens, we have designed a series of milestone-driven experiments using a novel collection of patient-derived and isogenic human induced pluripotent stem cells harboring NF1-patient germline NF1 gene mutations.

 

######**Study Design:**

The overall conceptual framework for this proposal is illustrated in the **Figure**, where the differential impact of the germline NF1 gene mutation in sensory neurons on human NF1-deficient Schwann cell growth will be analyzed.

 

${image?fileName=gutmann%2Epng&align=Center&scale=100&responsive=true}

# Project ID: syn9727752

${image?fileName=CTF Synodos Data Site Headers5%2Ejpg&align=Center&scale=100&responsive=true}
###**Welcome to the Synodos Schwannomatosis Data Portal**

Synodos for Schwannomatosis was a two-year initiative that will bring together basic, translational, and clinical researchers towards the end goal of developing effective treatments for schwannomatosis. The project aims to perform an extensive molecular analysis of schwannomatosis tumor samples to identify new therapeutic targets, and advance the understanding and management of the disease, with a focus on pain. Experts from institutions spread across four different countries are working together to:
1. Develop a clinically annotated schwannomatosis biobank;
2. Develop a comprehensive pain registry for schwannomatosis patients
3. Establish the genomic and epigenomic landscape of schwannomatosis to identify disease-driving alterations; and,
4. Correlate the molecular findings with key clinical parameters, including pain.

This site serves as the landing page for all data and analysis coming from this project. Further details can also be found on the [study details page](https://nf.synapse.org/Explore/Studies/DetailsPage?studyId=syn9727752) for this project on the [NF Data Portal](https://nf.synapse.org/).

If you are new to the project, please register for an account and learn how to start working with the data by reading the [Accessing the Data](https://www.synapse.org/#!Synapse:syn9727752/wiki/424913) page to the left.

# Project ID: syn4939916

##Transition to Confirmatory and Secondary Screening of Plexiform Neurofibroma Models in 96-well Format
**Initiative:** Unsolicited
 
**Name:** Raymond Mattingly, Ph.D.
**Contact Email:** rmatting@med.wayne.edu
**Dates:** 8-1-15 to 10-31-16
**Tumor Focus:** plexiform neurofibroma
**Application:** Translational models
 
**Background:** 
In our [primary NTAP project](syn7217928) we developed and optimized 3D models of NF1 plexiform neurofibromas (PNs) with the goal of providing efficient and effective systems for secondary screening of compounds that would be identified as promising new approaches for these tumors. Another primary NTAP project was performed at NCATS to screen for potential therapeutics using the CellTiter-Glo assay of proliferation as the read-out in a 1536-well 2D growth format.
 
**Goals of Project:** 
To prove that cells grown in 3D matrices, as compared to those growing in 2D (on plastic) will exhibit drug sensitivity that is a better clinical predictor. We will perform confirmatory and secondary assays in collaboration with NCATS. We will develop a 96-well format Cell-Titer Glo assay procedure for 2D and 3D PN cultures that will be useful for general confirmatory testing. We expect that the 2D results should directly reproduce those of the initial screen, i.e., that the outcome is independent of the platform (1536-well vs. 96-well) or performance site (NCATS vs. WSU). Further, with transition to the 3D culture, 96-well format assay, we will advance from confirmation to a secondary screen of initial results. We hypothesize that cells growing in 3D matrices, as compared to those growing in 2D on plastic, will exhibit drug sensitivity that is a better predictor of eventual clinical effectiveness.
 
**Impact:** 
1. We have developed and optimized assays of proliferation of 3D PN cultures in 96-well plates to provide secondary screening of potential drug treatments. 
2. The fact that some potential treatments for NF1 PNs, as defined by their ability to inhibit growth in 2D cultures, are much less active against the 3D PN models could be highly significant. Inherent resistance to initially promising compounds is often encountered when transferring from in vitro screens to subsequent in vivo testing. If the 3D models can better predict which screening hits are likely to subsequently fail to be effective then they will be of great value.
 

**Publications:** manuscript(s) in process

# Project ID: syn11374333

###Cutaneous Neurofibroma: Models, Biology and Translation

 

#####**PI:** Lu Q. Le, M.D., Ph.D. 
**University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center**

 

######**Background and Rationale:**  

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a genetic disorder that affects around 1:3000 live births. While the disease has nearly 100% penetrance in patients, NF1 has a diverse spectrum of manifestations. Hallmark traits of the disease include cafÃ©-au-lait macules, cutaneous neurofibromas (cNF), plexiform neurofibromas (pNF) and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNST), among other symptoms. In NF1 patients, cNFs usually arise at puberty and beyond, can range widely in size and number, and can cause itching, pain, superficial infections as well as psychosocial and cosmetic burdens. Currently, there is no approved therapeutic option for cNFs aside from elective surgery. The development of new therapeutic approaches for cNF will require an understanding of the cNF cellular origin that can be used to elucidate mechanisms that underpin cNF formation and growth. While biallelic inactivation of NF1 in neoplastic Schwann cells is essential for cNF formation, it is not sufficient, pointing to the critical roles of other genetic or epigenetic changes as well as extrinsic signals from other cell types in the tumor microenvironment. While the field has made significant inroads towards our understanding of these tumors, there are still gaps in our knowledge of cNF pathogenesis that could be addressed by the adoption of a systemic approach to decipher all the biological steps in cNF development from the cell of origin to tumor stage to identify the â€œrate limiting stepâ€ that can be therapeutically targeted to prevent or delay cNF formation. Therefore, in this application, we propose a set specific aims to fill this knowledge gap: We will define the identity of the cNF cell of origin in mice that will guide us to identify the cells of origin for human cNF. We will next decipher how the cell of origin and the tumor microenvironment contribute to drive cNF initiation that will uncover its pathogenesis to delineate biological steps and mechanisms in tumor development as well as generating of preclinical models system that elucidate cNF biology and enable preclinical therapeutic testing.

 

######**Goals, Innovation and Potential Impact:**
Our overall project will advance via two parallel but interwoven efforts: 

1. Characterize cNF cell of origin to trace their developmental origin as well as to define their phenotypes and interactions with the tumor microenvironment. This will provide a framework for elucidating the functional contributions of cNF cell of origin in neurofibroma development. 
2. To determine biological steps that are critical for cNF development. A major innovation in our work is linking these approaches in a synergistic manner to our novel neurofibroma models that can be used broadly to decipher the pathogenesis as well as pre-clinical models for therapeutic testing.

# Project ID: syn21650493


##Retina regeneration in zebrafish-Endogenous RGC replacement

##VRI Subgroup: 
Endogenous RGC Replacement

##Principal Investigator: 
Daniel Goldman, PhD (University of Michigan)

##Personnel:
Aresh Sahu, PhD (Post-Doc)
Jonathan Jui PhD (Post-Doc)
Sulochan Devi, PhD (Research Associate)
Muchu Zhou, PhD (Research Technician)

##Lay Abstract

NF1 is a disease resulting from reduced levels of neurofibromin 1 that functions as a tumor suppressor. One in five children with NF1 have optic nerve tumors that can lead to retinal ganglion cell death and blindness. One approach for treating NF1-related blindness is to regenerate retinal ganglion cells from endogenous stem cells. Because zebrafish use endogenous stem cells to regenerate retinal ganglion cells, we propose that understanding this process in fish will inform us of strategies for stimulating a similar process in humans. With this goal in mind, we aim to identify gene expression changes and small molecules that are sufficient to drive retina regeneration in zebrafish and test their effect on retina regeneration in mammals.

# Project ID: syn27761862

# Leveraging Synodos NF2 data to test novel single and combination drugs in NF2-deficient meningioma models
## CTF - Drug Discovery Initiative Registered Reports
### Principal Investigator: Vijaya Ramesh (PI), Lei Xu (Co-investigator)
### Project Lead / Data Coordinator: Roberta Beauchamp
### Institution: Massachusetts General Hospital
### Project Description:
Meningiomas arise from meningothelial arachnoid cap cells and are the most common primary intracranial tumors in adults. NF2 inactivation is frequently associated with primary atypical (WHO grade II) tumors. Meningiomas that progress despite surgery and radiation are responsible for significant morbidity and mortality. Therefore, effective systemic therapies are greatly needed. For meningioma modeling and preclinical drug screening, we employ human primary meningioma (MN) cell lines derived from surgically resected tumors and CRISPR-Cas9 genome-edited isogenic, human arachnoidal cell lines (ACs) that either express or lack NF2. Employing these models, we established that NF2-deficient meningiomas reveal aberrant activation of mTORC1/mTORC2 signaling, which led to clinical trials for NF2 and meningiomas. In Synodos for NF2 project, we undertook large-scale kinome, transcriptome and drug screening studies in our AC and MN cell models to identify other potential targets. Kinome and transcriptome data revealed increased activation and expression of several EPH receptor family tyrosine kinases (EPH-RTKs), Src family kinase members (SFKs) and c-KIT. Our large-scale drug screening efforts, in collaboration with NIH-NCATS, revealed a set of proteasome inhibitors exhibiting cytotoxic effects with selectivity toward NF2-null cells. Taken together, here we propose to examine three different drugs targeting the proteasome (provided by Millennium/Takeda Pharmaceutical, and two NUAK2 specific inhibitors alone and combined with TAK-228 (mTOR inhibitor) in 2 grade I and 2 grade II MN lines as well as human Schwann cells (SC) with NF2 loss. Anti-tumor efficacy of proteasome drugs will also be evaluated in orthotopic NF2-deficient SC and MN models. Our overall approach of leveraging the â€˜omics and drug screening results from Synodos for NF2 studies for further testing in our in vitro and orthotopic NF2-deficient in vivo meningioma models is timely, novel and will provide a framework to pursue new avenues in NF2 research and for clinical care.

# Project ID: syn11374341

###Microenvironmental targets of cutaneous neurofibromas: T-cells and mast cells as tumor contributors
 

#####**PIs:**  Juha and Sirkku Peltonen
**Institution**: University of Turku 
**E-mail**: uhpel@utu.fi and sipelto@utu.fi
 

######**Background and Rationale:**  

Immunity has a central and complex role in tumor growth, which can be utilized when developing new treatment modalities for tumors. To date, the role of immune system in cNFs has gained little attention. Transformed cells are normally eradicated by cooperation of innate and adaptive immune cells. Immune surveillance could be expected to recognize neurofibromin neoepitopes resulting from the second hit of the NF1 gene, but this is not taking place in cNFs. Mast cells are known to be abundant in cNFs and they are increasingly more interesting as druggable targets in tumor biology and neurogenic itch. It is also not known whether mast cells of cNFs are tumorigenic or anti- tumorigenic.

 

######**Expected Outcomes:**
To prove that T cells and mast cells are valid targets for the treatment of cNF. Elucidating the characteristics, roles and effects of these prominent tumor microenvironment components in promoting tumorigenesis could be used to facilitate finding of targeted therapies for the treatment of cNF. The therapeutic modalities include those already approved and those being developed for tumor biology as well as for inflammatory diseases.

 

######**Challenges/Gaps:**
There are challenges in the sensitivity of mass spectrometry with single cell samples. T cell receptor sequencing is advancing fast but to date the algorithms still need to be developed to predict T cell specificity form T cell receptor sequence.

# Project ID: syn11374337

###Use of the mouse model of cutaneous NFs for identification of cells of origin and drug screening studies
 

#####**PI:** Piotr Topilko

 

######**Background and Rationale:**  


Despite major progress in the understanding of the mechanisms driving development of NFs, the cells of origin and scenario governing initiation of cNFs, remains unknown. We have recently shown that the neural crest derived boundary cap (BC) cells, transiently present at the interface between central and peripheral nervous system in a mouse embryo, migrate sequentially along nerve roots and along peripheral nerves under the skin, two locations where NFs develop with a higher incidence in NF1 patients. Furthermore, in the adult skin, BC derivatives correspond to various types of Schwann cells and dermal stem cells with gliogenic potential, two cell populations considered as the primary pathogenic target of NF1. Based on these observations, we hypothesized that BCs could be directly implicated in the development NFs. To explore such possibility, we have generated mouse line carrying NF1 loss combined with fluorescent tracer in BC cells and their derivatives. All mutant mice develop both paraspinal plexiform and cutaneous NFs whose location and cellular composition faithfully recapitulates NFs present in human NF1 patients.

 

######**Goal:**

The aim of this study is to take advantage of this unique model and our extensive expertise of NF1 pathology and of mechanisms governing the development of Schwann cells to tackle three important issues concerning the _initiation and progression_, _cellular origin_ and _novel treatment_ of cNFs.

 

######**Collaboration:**

The success of this project implies close collaboration with two other Partners: the team of Dr. Anne-Marie Schmitt from Pierre Fabre Research Institute and of Professor Pierre Wolkenstein from Hopital Henri Mondor, both from France. Together, we propose well-integrated and complementary aims requiring the specific skills and knowledge of all Partners that are indispensable for the technical and conceptual aspects of this study.

Results from some of this work have been published in Cancer Discovery (Radomska, et al. Cancer Discovery, 2019).  [Click here](http://cancerdiscovery.aacrjournals.org/content/9/1/130.long)

# Project ID: syn11638893

###Development of a Preclinical NF1-MPNST Platform Suitable for Precision Oncology Drug Discovery and Evaluation
 
#####**PI:**  Angela C. Hirbe, MD, PhD

**Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis**

 

######**Technical Background and Rationale:** 

One of the most common malignancies affecting adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) are malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs), highly aggressive sarcomas that typically develop from benign plexiform neurofibromas. 8-13% of individuals with NF1 will develop MPNSTs during young adulthood.  There are few therapeutic options, and the vast majority of people with these cancers will die within 5 years of diagnosis. Despite advances in our understanding of the pathobiology of these tumors and the identification of seemingly-promising therapeutic targets using a single mouse MPNST model system (NPCis mice and derivative cell lines), no investigational agents have demonstrated efficacy following translation to human clinical trials. However, there is limited genetic diversity being modeled in these systems, which does not capture the full spectrum of genetic diversity that characterizes human NF1-MPNSTs. In this regard, p53 loss, a common feature of the currently-used preclinical models, is observed in a minority of human MPNSTs. We hypothesize that one of the major reasons that rationally-chosen drugs underperform in human clinical trials is that the preclinical models used to discover and evaluate promising therapeutic agents do not capture the genetic heterogeneity of the human cancer. To optimize clinical translation, we aim to develop a collection of MPNST Patient Derived Xenografts (MPNST-PDXs) for the NF community, which more fully represent the spectrum of genetic heterogeneity seen in the human condition.  

 

######**Hypothesis and Specific Aims:**

Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) are aggressive sarcomas, which occur at an increased frequency in individuals with NF1, where they often arise from a benign plexiform neurofibroma. Currently, the only curative therapy involves complete surgical resection; however, this is often impossible due to the size or the degree of invasiveness of the primary tumor or the presence of metastatic disease at diagnosis.  In this situation, therapy is often limited to standard cytotoxic chemotherapy or enrollment in a clinical trial using rationally-chosen molecularly-targeted therapies.  Despite advances in our understanding of the biology of MPNSTs, no successful clinical trials have resulted in improved survival for individuals with NF1-MPNST. For example, while EGFR inhibition was effective in shrinking murine Nf1/p53 MPNSTs,1 no activity was demonstrated in a phase II clinical trial.2 Similarly, subsequent trials also based on preclinical model successes failed to show efficacy when translated to human clinical trials (sorafenib or imatinib). **We hypothesize that the poor translation of preclinical findings to the bedside reflect three barriers: **

1. current preclinical models do not encompass the spectrum of genetic heterogeneity observed in human MPNSTs 
2. Treatments may work better for one disease subtype, which is currently not captured using a single genetic model, and 
3. NF1-MPNSTs may develop adaptive mechanisms that allow for escape from the effects of therapy. 

 

In this proposal, we plan to **address those _three barriers_ **by: 
1. generating human preclinical models that more fully recapitulate the genetic diversity seen in human NF1-MPNSTs, 
2. evaluating the responsiveness to conventional and targeted therapies using a diverse collection of patient-derived MPNST xenograft models, and 
3. defining potential therapeutic escape mechanisms. The generation of these NF1-MPNST lines will serve as a valuable resource for the NF research community relevant to the design and evaluation of future therapeutic strategies to treat NF1-MPNST.

 

######**Objectives:**
The main goal of this research project is to develop a set of NF1-MPNST PDX lines that captures the spectrum of molecular heterogeneity of the human disease. The proposal aims to meet the following objectives:

a. Create enabling resources including 10 NF1-MPNST PDX lines for preclinical studies.
b. Histologically and genomically characterize these 10 NF1-MPNST PDX lines, thereby defining the molecular heterogeneity of these tumors.
c. Determine whether there is a correlation between molecular subtype and response to chemotherapy or targeted therapy.
d. Assess potential adaptive mechanisms or tumor resistance by assessing genomic changes following treatment.

 

######**Milestones and Deliverables:**

**Period 1 objectives a and b:**
Define MPNST molecular heterogeneity by developing and characterizing NF1-MPNST Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) lines.
â€¢ Histologic characterization of 4 lines
â€¢ Begin development of two more lines
â€¢ Send RNA and DNA for sequencing on 5 lines (the line used as preliminary data in the grant and the 4 others characterized above)

 

**Period 2 objectives a and b:**
Define MPNST molecular heterogeneity by developing and characterizing NF1-MPNST Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) lines.
â€¢ Histologic characterization of 2 lines
â€¢ Begin development of one more line
â€¢ Send RNA and DNA for sequencing on 3 lines

 

**Period 3 objectives a and b:**
Define MPNST molecular heterogeneity by developing and characterizing NF1-MPNST Patient-Derived Xenograft (PDX) lines.
â€¢ Generation of 2 PDX lines
â€¢ Histologic characterization of 2 PDX lines
â€¢ Send RNA and DNA for sequencing on 2 lines

 

**Period 4 objective c:**
Determine whether there is a correlation between the specific mutational subtype and the response of the tumors to conventional therapy.
â€¢ In vivo murine experiments with anthracyclines

 

**Period 5 objective c:**
Determine whether there is a correlation between the specific mutational subtype and the response of the tumors to targeted therapy.
â€¢ In vivo murine experiments with mTOR inhibitors and potentially other drugs

 

**Period 6 objective d:**
Assess potential adaptive mechanisms of tumor resistance by examining changes in gene expression following treatment.
â€¢ In vivo murine experiments with sequencing and other tumor analyses post treatment with chemotherapy and targeted agents

# Project ID: syn23662493


# Developing an Improved mAb Against Neurofibromin

### **Principal Investigator:** Michelle Mattson-Hoss, PhD
### **Company:** Infixion Bioscience, Inc.

### Project Description: 
Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder in which the amount of wild type neurofibromin produced by the remaining functional gene is a significant factor in the progression and severity of NF1 symptoms (i.e., haploinsufficiency driven). Given neurofibrominâ€™s impact in regulating the Ras pathway and the importance of neurofibromin protein levels directly impacting many downstream pathways the availability of sensitive and specific antibodies to facilitate protein measurement becomes critically important.

Unfortunately, commercially available NF1 antibodies (both polyclonal and monoclonal) have been shown to have significant limitations, including the inability to use these antibodies in ELISA and IHC applications. Utilizing full-length neurofibromin (isolated and purified by the Frank McCormick lab and Dominic Espositoâ€™s team at the Frederick National Lab) as the immunogen, and leveraging a proprietary antibody development platform, AlicantoÂ©, from Digital Proteomics, LLC, the San Diego-based team at Infixion Bioscience set out to develop a new and improved monoclonal antibody against NF1. Project goals include:
1) identifying a mAb with increased sensitivity and specificity against neurofibromin as determined by western blot, and 
2) demonstrate expanded utility with function in ELISAs, sandwich ELISAs and immunohistochemistry (IHC) applications.

Additional collaborating partners on the project included: Dr. Michael Frost (IHC development), Dr. Dominic Esposito (epitope mapping), and Dr. Eduard Serra Lab (characterization in NF1 iPSC lines).

# Project ID: syn4939888

##Development of Patient Reported Outcomes System for Patients with NF1-Associated Plexiform Neurofibromas using Mixed Method Approach
**Initiative:** PRO
 
**Name:** Jin-Shei Lai, Ph.D.
**Contact Email:** js-lai@northwestern.edu 
**Dates:** 2-1-14 to 5-31-18
**Tumor Focus:** Plexiform Neurofibroma
**Application:** Clinical Endpoint Tool
 
**Background:** 
Patient Reported Outcome (PRO) measures assess the treatment outcomes most relevant to patients, and constitute potential outcomes to evaluate in clinical trials. PROs meeting FDA guidelines are critical to ensuring patient-centered endpoints are incorporated. Historically, NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas (pNF) treatment trials have under-utilized PROs specific to pNF. A psychometrically sound measure incorporating input from patients, families and clinicians, is critical for inclusion in treatment trials. To address the need for a pNF-specific PRO measure for use in clinical trials, this project sought to develop a PRO measurement system utilizing input from patients, families and clinicians, as well as well as psychometric analysis methods to ensure the developed measures are reliable and valid.
 
**Goals of Project:** 
Advancing a PRO system for children and young adults with pNF by (1) establishing a conceptual model describing HRQOL, 2) Developing item pools (e.g.,  pain, stigma, and organ dysfucntion measures), 3) Evaluating psychometric properties of the pools, 4) affirming clinical differences.
 
**Specific Aims:** 
1a. To establish a conceptual model describing health-related quality of life (HRQOL) for patients with pNF across the lifespan via individual interviews with patients, parents, and clinicians. This ensures inclusion of the patientâ€™s voice in future clinical trials. 
1b. To develop item pools based on findings from Aim 1a and literature review. We anticipated that pain, stigma and organ dysfunction measures would be developed, with the possibility of additional domains, some from existing instruments. 
2. To develop a PRO system for patients with pNF across the lifespan by evaluating the psychometric properties of the existing, modified, and newly developed item pools from Aim 1. 
3. To establish clinically important differences (IDs) for the PRO system developed in Aim 2. This will enable evaluation of clinical interventionsâ€™ impact upon patient-reported symptoms using clinically-based and psychometrically-sound methodology consistent with FDA guidance for PROs.
